Sir,

I beg to report that owing to a bad attack of eczema on the hands and face of the teacher at Big Eddy, the school has been temporarily closed. It may, or may not be necessary to get another teacher. Ottawa, March 29, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th instant reporting that owing to a bad attack of eczema on the face and hands of the teacher at Big Bay the school has been temporarily closed and that you will consult with Rev. Dean Fraser to allow Mr. Bird to carry on the work temporarily.

In reply I beg to say that, in order to keep this school open, Mr. Bird may be placed in charge temporarily.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. R. Taylor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
Referring to Department letter No. 118 339/1 dated March 29th, 1916 re. Mr. Bird's temporary appointment to the Big Eddy School, I beg to say that Robert Thomas has recovered sufficiently to resume his duties.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant.

Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.
I have the honor to report the enlistment of Robert Thomas Jr., who was teacher at the Big Eddy day school. He enlisted on the spur of the moment and did not give the usual notice of his intention to leave. I have taken the matter up with Rural Dean Fraser, and he says as soon as Arch. MacKay arrives at the Pas, which will be in the near future, it will be arranged that Mr. Bird will take over the school temporarily. It will be remembered that permission was given for Mr. Bird to carry on the school in Department letter No. 118339/1 dated March 29th 1916.

I have the honor to be

Sir;

Your obedient servant.

[Signature]

The Asst. Deputy Indian Agent.

and Secretary,

Ottawa Can.

Ottawa, September 7, 1916.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo reporting the enlistment of Robert Thomas, Jr., teacher of the Big Eddy Day School, and stating that you have taken the matter up with Rural Dean Fraser, who says that as soon as Archdeacon MacKay arrives at The Pas it will be arranged that Mr. Bird will take over the school temporarily.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of Mr. Bird being placed in charge of this school temporarily.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. R. Taylor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, file 502-1, part 1)
I beg to report that Mr. Bird's clerical duties prevented him from taking charge of the Big Eddy day school. Rural Dean Fraser recommended the appointment of Sarah McGillivary, an ex-pupil of the Elkhorn Industrial School. Her maiden name being Sarah Cook. I accepted Mr. Fraser's recommendation and have allowed her to open school. I consider her able to teach the small children who attend this school, and recommend her appointment.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your Obedient servant.

Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa Can.
Ottawa, November 14, 1916.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 7th instant I beg to say that the Department approves of the temporary appointment of Sarah McGillivray as teacher of the Big Eddy Day School and that she will be paid at the rate of $400.00 per annum for her services.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. R. Taylor, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE,

The Pas, Man.

April 18th, 1917.

Sir,

Sarah McGillivray has resigned the Big Eddy Day School and left there on Mar. 31st. on account of illness. On the recommendation of the church authorities I have installed Joe Chamberlain who resigned the Cumberland School on that date. In the meantime the school has been closed unknown to me. Mrs McGillivray's resignation was sent to the church authorities and only came to me on this date, so I installed Chamberlain at once as the attendance at this school is good.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Acting Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.

Ottawa, April 26, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant stating that Sarah McGillivray has resigned as teacher of the Big Eddy Day School and left there on the 31st ultimo on account of illness and that, on the recommendation of the church authorities, you have installed Jos. Chamberlain, who resigned the Cumberland School.

In reply I beg to say that your action in placing Mr. Chamberlain in charge of the Big Eddy School is approved and he will be paid at the rate of $400.00 per annum for his services.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE

The Pas, Man.

Sept. 28th, 1917

Sir,

I beg to report that the beginning of the school term Joseph Chamberlain, teacher of the Big Eddy day school left without notice to accept a position at the Barrier Public School and in my absence the Rev. Mr. Fraser had Mrs. Sarah McGillivary who was acting teacher last winter take over the school, and I would like the Dept. Authority for appointment as teacher for this school. Her husband has enlisted with No. 5 Forestry Draft.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Acting Indian Agent.

The Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, file 502-1, part 1)
Ottawa, October 12, 1917.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 25th ultimo reporting that, at the beginning of the school term, Joseph Chamberlain, teacher of the Big Eddy School, left without notice to accept a position at the Barrier Public School and in your absence the Rev. Mr. Fraser had Mrs. Sarah McGillivray, who was acting teacher last winter, take over the school.

In reply I beg to say that the Department approves of the appointment of Mrs. McGillivray as teacher of the Big Eddy School and she will be paid at the same rate as before, viz.- $400.00 per annum.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

S. L. Macdonald, Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent.
The Pas, Man.

IN INDIAN AGENT'S OFFICE

The Pas, Manitoba,

December 29th 1919

I have the honour to report that Thos. Badger, a man who reports that he has taught Indian Day Schools, the last being Moose Lake Day School, has applied for the position as School Teacher at Big Eddy. I informed him that Mr. McGillivray would probably take the school over again in six months or a year and he states that this would be satisfactory to him if he got the position. I did not quote him any salary, as I do not know what the Department wishes to give him, but if his application is accepted by the Department, I would be obliged if I could be informed by wire the amount of salary to offer him so that I can settle this before he starts work.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

I have the honour to report that the School Teacher at Big Eddy Day School has asked to be allowed to resign from her position. She states that she would like a holiday for a year and would be obliged if the Department will let her go. I would recommend that she be allowed to resign.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
SEND the following NIGHT LETTER subject to the terms printed on the back hereof, which are hereby agreed to.

J. W. Waddy,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Department wishes to consult Bishop Newnham before appointing teacher Big Kidy Bay School. Thomas Badger may take charge temporarily until teacher nominated by Bishop takes charge. Salary will be at rate of four hundred dollars.

J. D. McLean.

Ottawa, January 3, 1920.
Ottawa, January 3, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 29th ultimo, in which you inform the Department that Mrs. McMillan, teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, asked to be allowed to resign her position.

In reply I beg to say that her resignation is accepted. The Department cannot undertake to re-engage her services after a year's absence.

I have also to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the same date, in which you recommend that Thomas Badger, who formerly taught the Moose Lake School, be appointed to succeed Mrs. McMillan.

In reply I beg to confirm the following night lettergram, which I sent you today: "Department wishes to consult Bishop Newnham before appointing teacher Big Eddy Day School. Thomas Badger may take charge temporarily until teacher nominated by Bishop takes charge. Salary will be at rate of four hundred dollars."

As the Big Eddy Day School is conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, the Department desires to consult His Lordship Bishop Newnham regarding the appointment of a teacher. His Lordship is being requested to nominate a suitable teacher for this school.

In the meantime, in order that the school may not be closed, Mr. Badger may assume charge temporarily, if he will do so, until such time as the services of a regularly qualified teacher are secured. During the period that Mr. Badger is temporarily employed the Department will allow him salary at the rate of $400.00 per annum.

As soon as the Department is informed by Bishop Newnham as to the name of the teacher he secures you will be advised.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Neidly, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa, January 3, 1920.

Right Reverend Sir,

The Department is in receipt of a communication from Mr. Agent Weedy, The Pas, forwarding the resignation of Mrs. McCallum as teacher of the Big Bird Indian Day School and recommending the appointment of Thomas Badger to succeed her.

The Agent states that Mrs. McCallum would like to be granted leave of absence for a year, when she would resume duty. The Agent is being informed that the Department will accept the resignation of Mrs. McCallum, but cannot consent to re-engage her at the end of a year.

With reference to Thomas Badger I beg to say that he formerly taught the Moose Lake Day School, but, as he has no qualifications, it is considered that it would be unwise to appoint him permanently.

I have to request that Your Lordship will be good enough to endeavour to secure the services of a properly qualified teacher. The name and qualifications of such teacher secured by Your Lordship should be forwarded for the approval of the Department. The Department will be prepared to pay an increased salary for a qualified teacher. The returns received show that there are 34 children on the roll, with an average attendance of about 20. It should be pointed out that Your Lordship would give this matter your early attention and endeavour to secure the services of a qualified teacher. The salary which you consider he should receive should also be stated.

In the meantime, in order that the school will not be closed and the children deprived of school privileges, the Department respectfully asks you to appoint Thomas Badger temporarily until such time as the services of a qualified teacher are obtained.

It is hoped that Your Lordship will be able to nominate a suitable teacher for this school at an early date.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Ass't Deputy and Secretary,
Right Rev. J. A. Newnham, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert, Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, file 502-1, part 1)
Sir,

Replying to your letter of January 3rd, No. 118339/1, I have the honour to report that Thos. Badger would not accept the position of teacher of the Big Eddy Day School at the salary mentioned, and that Mrs. McGillivary has withdrawn her resignation and has again taken charge of the school.

I will be very much obliged if the Department will allow Mrs. McGillivary to withdraw her resignation and continue at the same salary as previously given her.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Indian Agent

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, January 20, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant informing the Department that Thomas Redger, whose appointment temporarily as teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School was approved by official letter of the 3rd instant, will not accept the position, and that Mrs. McGillivray, former teacher, has withdrawn her resignation and has again resumed duty.

In reply I beg to say that His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan was requested to endeavour to secure the services of a properly qualified teacher for this school and, before the Department can sanction the re-appointment of Mrs. McGillivray, it will await the approval of His Lordship, who is being written to regarding the matter. In the meantime Mrs. McGillivray may assume charge temporarily and, if His Lordship agrees to her re-engagement, you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Weddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man
Ottawa, January 20, 1920.

Right Reverend Sir,

With reference to official letter to Your Lordship of the instant regarding the appointment of a teacher for the Big Judy Indian Day School I beg to say that a communication has been received from Mr. Agent Weady, the Pas, in which he states that Thomas Badger, who was appointed temporarily pending the appointment of a qualified teacher, would not accept the position at the salary offered, namely, $400.00 per annum, and that Mrs. McGillivray, the former teacher, has withdrawn her resignation and has again taken charge of this school.

Before approving of the re-engagement of Mrs. McGillivray I have to request that Your Lordship will inform the Department whether you approve of her continuing in the work as teacher of this school. In the meantime the Agent is being informed that her temporary appointment is approved by the Department, pending the approval of Your Lordship.

The Department will be pleased to hear from Your Lordship at your early convenience as to whether you have any other teacher in view, and, if not, whether you will agree to the re-appointment of Mrs. McGillivray.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Right Rev. J. A. Newnham, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert, Sask.

J. D. McLEAN
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.
Sir,

In reference to your letter No. 118339/1 of the 20th inst., in regards to school teacher at Big Eddy Day School, I will be very much obliged if the Department will advise me just how the Missionaries are connected with the Day School Teachers in this Agency, as I cannot find any reference to the matter in the files in this Office.

I may say that it will be very hard to get a decent Teacher for any position in our Day Schools here unless we give them higher salaries, they cannot live on the Indian Department Salary at present, and I understand from some of our teachers that they receive nothing from the Church in the way of salary, so I would be very much obliged to know just how this matters stands.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dep't. Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, February 6, 1920

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the appointment of day school teachers in your agency.

In reply I beg to say that as these schools are conducted under the auspices of the Church of England the authorities of that church are allowed to nominate teachers.

With reference to the salary paid, I beg to say that the Department would be disposed to pay a much higher salary than at present provided properly qualified teachers are obtained. In the past teachers secured by the schools in your agency have had little, if any, qualifications and the success they have met with has not been such as would warrant the payment of higher salaries.

The Department is not aware as to whether the church authorities augment the teachers' salaries.

Your obedient servant

J.D. MOLLEN

Assistant Deputy and Secretary

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas,
Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, file 502-1, part 1)
Sir,

I have the honor to report that the teacher of Big Edgy Day School, Mrs. McGillivary, is leaving her position at the end of June. Her family is moving about ten miles up the river and she is going with them.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 20, 1921

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st ultimo, informing the Department that Mrs. McGillivray, teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, intends giving up her duties at the end of the current quarter, namely, June 30th, next.

In this connection I beg to say that the Department is taking up the question of obtaining the services of a teacher, to begin duties when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, with His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan, under whose auspices the school is conducted. As soon as a suitable teacher has been nominated by His Lordship, you will be further advised.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Pas., Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, file 502-1, part 1)
Ottawa, May 30, 1921.

Right Reverend Sir,

The Department has been advised that Mrs. McGillivray, teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, is giving up her duties at the end of the current quarter, namely, June 30th, next. Her family is moving from the locality and she intends going with them.

I would be pleased if Your Lordship would nominate a suitable teacher to succeed her, to begin duties when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, or about the first of September next.

If a teacher having a professional qualification is secured, the Department will be prepared to pay a higher salary than was allowed Mrs. McGillivray, the amount to depend on the qualifications, etc.

It is hoped that you will be able to secure a teacher for this school in time for its re-opening in September next. The name, qualifications and experience of the person nominated by you should be submitted for the approval of the Department.

I have the honour to be

Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean,
Assistant Deputy and Secretary

Right Rev. T. A. Newham, D.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
Prince Albert,
Sask.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, file 502-1, part 1)
Sir,

I have the honor to report that Mary Jane Cook, an ex-pupil from McKay Boarding School, who belongs to the Pas Reserve has applied for the position as teacher at the Big Eddy Day School on Pas Reserve. This girl is twenty-two years old and is a sister of Mrs. McGillivary, who taught this school until the end of last term. Miss Cook often took the classes while her sister was teacher and I beg to recommend that the Department give her the position.

Reverend Mr. Fraser tells me that the Bishop is agreeable to this appointment. Mrs. McGillivary received $400.00 a year and bonus, but this is very small when you consider the cost of living at this point, and if possible I think the Department should allow a slightly higher salary than this.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
OTTAWA, Sept. 7th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3lst ultimo, recommending that Mary Jane Cook, an ex-pupil of the McKay Boarding School, be appointed to the position as teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, and stating that you have been informed that His Lordship, The Bishop of Saskatchewan, is agreeable to her appointment.

In reply, I beg to say that in order that this school may not remain closed, the Department will approve of the temporary appointment of Miss Cook. Her retention in the position, however, to depend upon the success she meets with in her work.

The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $450 per annum, and she will also be entitled to receive the bonus provided by law. This bonus will be paid at the rate of $15.00 per month during the period covered by her service to the end of the present fiscal year.

You will be good enough to state the date on which she assumes charge, and you should arrange with her to reopen the school as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
OTTAWA, Sept. 7th, 1921.

Right Reverend Sir,

Mr. Agent Waddy, The Pas, recommends that Mary Jane Cook, an ex-pupil of the McKay Boarding School, be appointed teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School. This girl is twenty-two years of age and is a sister of Mrs. McGillivray, the former teacher.

The agent states that he has been informed that this appointment would be acceptable to Your Lordship. The Department is approving of the temporary appointment of this girl. Her retention in the position, however, to depend upon the success she meets in her work.

The salary allowed her will be at the rate of $450 per annum, together with the bonus provided by law to teachers in Indian day schools.

The agent has been informed of her appointment and requested to have her reopen the school as soon as possible.

It is hoped that this will meet with your approval.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst.-Deputy & Secretary.

Right Rev. J. A. Newnham, C.D.,
Bishop of Saskatchewan,
PRINCE ALBERT, SASK.
OTTAWA, Sept. 7th, 1921.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that on the recommendation of Mr. Agent Waddy, the Department is appointing Mary Jane Cook, an ex-pupil of the McKay Boarding School, as teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School. The agent states that this appointment will meet with the approval of His Lordship, The Bishop of Saskatchewan.

The salary allowed is at the rate of $450 per annum, together with bonus provided to teachers of Indian day schools during the present fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
Prince Albert, Sask.

Sep. 12th 1921

Sir,

In reply to your letter No. 128-15-1 of the 16th inst., addressed to the Bishop of Saskatchewan, I have to say that the appointment of Mary Ann Cook as teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School will be quite acceptable and it is hoped that she will make a success of her work.

Yours obediently,

J. A. Mackay

The Secretary
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose herewith the report for September quarter from the teacher at Big Edgy Day School.

In reference to letter #128-15-1 of the 7th ultimo, regarding re-opening this school I beg to say that it was opened on September 19th, and I visited the school on the 22nd. The teacher was getting well started with the work. There are 40 children on the register, but a number of these have been carried on the book for a long time and have not attended. I think the average attendance for next quarter will be about 20.

I enclose herewith a list of material asked for and think it should be charged to band fund #233 as the whole community helped to break the windows I suppose and it is not a school matter chargeable to vote 7.

I am, Sir, Your obedient servant,

Asst Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Sir,

I have the honor to report that on the 12th inst., I visited the Big Eddy Day School on the Pas Res Reserve.

The teacher is Miss Mary Jane Cook, an ex-pupil of Mackay Boarding school. This girl has made fair progress with the children in grades one and two, but the pupil in grade three seems to be just too far advanced, I think the teacher will have difficulty in teaching in standard three.

There are twenty six children on the register, with sixteen present at time of my visit, though the average for the quarter will not be more than ten, as the trappers were away with the children all spring.

Five children were in A.B.C. class. Seven are in Standard one who can read, spell, add, subtract, multiply, write and draw. Three are in standard two who do much the same work and who can describe in English all local objects pointed out. One pupil is in standard three who seemed to know less than the ones in standard two.

The school was fairly tidy, and the children were clean.

I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Sir,

I have the honor to enclose the report of the teacher at Big Eddy Day School for the September quarter.

The teacher has been sick for past two months and only opened the school for a few days. I advised closing the school for a short time as it appeared as if the teacher was developing T.B. but the medical officer thinks she may soon get well and be able to continue her work.

I am, Sir,
Your obedient servant,

[Signature]
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Indian Agent,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
OTTAWA, October 16th, 1922.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing the September quarter return of the Big Eddy Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say it is noted that, through illness, the teacher had school open only a few days in the quarter. If this teacher is unable to continue duties after a reasonable length of time, it might be well for you to ask for her resignation, and obtain the services of a qualified teacher.

We hope to hear from you later as to whether Miss Cook has sufficiently recovered her health to resume duties, and also the dates between which the school was closed on account of her ill-health.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
Sir,

In reference to letter 128-15-1 of the 16th ultimo, I beg to report that the teacher of Big Eddy Day School resumed her duties on the 1st inst.

I visited the school yesterday. There were 16 boys and 15 girls on the register, present 8 boys and 4 girls. Two pupils were in Standard 2 and were making good progress considering the time the school was closed. Five pupils were in senior Standard 1 and were also getting along very well. The balance were A.B.C. pupils.

The building was kept clean, but will require a coat of paint or white wash next spring.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent

Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, Nov. 24, 1922.

Sir:-

I have your letter of the 17th instant, informing the Department that Miss Cook, Teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, resumed duties on the first instant.

You may draw to the attention of the Department, next spring, the need of having the school building painted or whitewashed and, at the same time, you should furnish an estimate of the cost of having the work done. Consideration will then be given to authorising it.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.
Extract from Inspector's Report on the Big Bay School, June 5, 1923.

-------------------

Teacher.- Miss Mary Jane Cook - 23 years.
Salary .- $450.00

Qualifications.- In the fifth grade when left MacKay Boarding School.

Health.- Good.

Suggestions.- I consider this standing too low for a teacher. We cannot expect much from a grade IV or V pupil.

My only suggestion would be to secure a teacher with a higher certificate or standing.

J. S. Peach.

Extract from Commissioner Graham's letter of June 19, 1923 enclosing the above report -

"This report is not satisfactory in my opinion as this is an important school there being 30 children enrolled. The teacher has not the qualifications and Mr. Peach's recommendation that another teacher should be engaged is no doubt well founded.

W. M. Graham.

Commissioner."
Ottawa, June 28, 1923.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, draws attention to the work being performed by the teacher, Miss Mary Jane Cook. He states that little or no progress is being made, owing to the fact that the teacher has no qualifications and that her educational standing is too low for a teacher. He recommends that another teacher be secured, with a higher certificate or standing.

The Inspector's recommendation that another teacher be engaged is, no doubt, well founded, and it is considered that the services of Miss Cook should be dispensed with and another teacher obtained, to begin duties when the school re-opens after the summer holidays, on or about September first, next. I have, therefore, to request that you will take this matter up with the Church authorities, and every effort should be made to secure the services of a qualified teacher for this school for next year. We would be pleased to allow a higher salary if a suitable teacher is secured - the amount to depend upon the qualifications of the person engaged. The name, qualifications and experience of any applicants should be forwarded for the consideration of the Department.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned to Prince Albert after a long round of the Indian missions of the North.

BIG EDDY DAY SCHOOL

I had a large deputation of the Indians including the Chief and all the councillors urging me to apply to the Department for a new school to replace the old log thing that Miss Millan has at Big Eddy. Dear Mr. Williams:

I visited this school on September 28th, 1932. Since my last inspection, Miss Ingram has been appointed teacher. She is not a qualified teacher and has no standing in this country. Miss Ingram appears quite alert, employs fairly good methods in her work, but it seems unfortunate, when we have so many qualified teachers in our own province who are unable to obtain schools and who would gladly work for the same salary, that they could not be employed in these positions. I think we should insist that qualified teachers be placed in charge of our classrooms.

The roll calls for 20 pupils and 14 were present on the day of my visit. The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 7      |
| II    | 4      |
| III   | 3      |
| IV    | 6      |

A PLEA FOR THE PEOPLE

by Sidney Bingham

The people are friendly

A HAPPY GROUP AT GILLAM
The big girl, who speaks English well, was the writer's guide and interpreter
Have you ever stopped to think of the most despised and rejected of all the inhabitants of Canada? In their own language, they call themselves "The People", for they lived in this land long before white men searching for the Indies, stopped here and called them Indians.

Before the white man came, the People were free to wander as they pleased, hunting and trapping just enough to provide for their immediate needs, but not attempting to gather together stores or possessions which would be cumbersome as they travelled about. Their wants were few, so they were healthy and carefree as they wandered along well-trodden trails or were carried downstream in their birch-bark canoes. They did not live as the white man does, because many of his ways are ill-adapted to the needs of wanderers in the silent North; but they lived well and happily, according to their standard, and were entirely self-supporting.

By nature, the People are calm, friendly, affectionate folk with a keen sense of humour and a great love of family life. Their innate reverence for the power of a great Creator manifests itself very clearly when they come under the influence of the Christian Church, and their childlike devotion is a shining example of piety for the scores of professing Christians who seem to think that religion may be put on and off with their Sunday clothes. People who visit Indians in their tents will see good and bad homes, just as they do in any Canadian town or village. Nowhere, however, will they see superfluous possessions and they will probably be filled with amazement that human beings can subsist on so little.
They will realize that there is no possibility of keeping extra supplies for unexpected illness or even the feebleness of old age. They will see children who are obviously undernourished and dogs that are on the verge of starvation. Those who are familiar with the requirements of good camping will find many illustrations of this, despite glaring exceptions and a certain superficial untidiness which gives a straggly appearance everywhere. In many families, clothes are washed frequently, tents are aired, and food is securely protected from flies and stray animals; while camp fires and shelters of all types are used, according to individual needs. Dirt and disease are found certainly; but they are not so universal as some folk would have us believe, and a visit to an Indian camp in summertime is decidedly more pleasant than one paid to a slum tenement house at the same season of the year. The much-discussed "laziness" of the race is only partially true, and where it does exist, it is due mainly to lack of ambition caused by malnutrition or by the evil effects of unwise charity. Added to all this, there is a dull hopelessness which is the direct result of the treatment accorded to Indians by the very men whose greed for gain has robbed the inhabitants of the North of their means of subsistence—the wild animals which provided them with food, clothing, shelter and wholesome activity. Despite all the stories of tribal feuds and evil practices, the primitive life of North American Indians in the early days was mainly a healthy and wholesome one which gave men time to enjoy something of the "Peace which passeth all understanding."

Then came the white man. Soon the Indian discovered that his furs were of use, not only for clothing himself and his family or for making sleeping-robles, but also for barter. In exchange for them, he received knives and guns and bright trinkets that seemed to represent wealth. Greed for gain grew in the heart of the Indian then, and so he began to trap more animals than he needed in order to exchange their furs for the new treasures that were offered him. The white man was trapping too, so gradually the precious animals became less plentiful, and sometimes Indian women and children were cold and hungry. Before long, white men came to settle in these parts and the Indian began to live on their food, much of which was put up in bright tin cans. Perhaps it was not so nourishing, but it tasted good and could easily be obtained if one had something to trade for it. But when the Indian had nothing to trade he had to go hungry or to wander much further to find the animals that gave him food and clothing.
Gradually the Indians grew poorer as their white brothers became rich.

That was not all, however, for other troubles arose. The Indian girls were happy and handsome, but white men brought sorrow to many a maiden's heart.

A few of the newcomers settled down honourably with Indian wives, and thereby put themselves "beyond the pale" of local groups of white people; but most of them moved on, leaving behind them, in due course, little Pale-faces to be brought up in poverty-stricken Indian camps. Sometimes too, the strangers who came to trade in the North gave the Indians "fire-water", and that caused more misery. Then, through the well-meant efforts of government officials, treaties were made and reserves set aside. These brought a measure of protection from exploitation but they also had evil effects. Treaty money seemed untold wealth to the struggling Indians, and other privileges made them settle down calmly to a life of ease. They forgot their old skills and failed to learn new ones. Benevolent ladies from afar sent them great bales of clothing which were often distributed indiscriminately, and made them feel that there was no longer any need to go hunting for warm furs. Thus it came about that strong men lay about in their tents or learned bad habits from the less desirable types of whites in settlements nearby. Those who still tried to hunt became discouraged and came home hungry, because wild animals had fled with the coming of the white men. There was a tendency for the Indians to crowd together round the trading posts, and some of them even took to living in stuffy houses instead of tents. Tuberculosis appeared and still more loathesome diseases were spread by the dregs of the white population which pushed ever northwards in the wild rush for valuable furs. Gradually many of the Indians tended to abandon their old healthy, independent, carefree way of life for an existence that was miserable beyond description, or else entirely irresponsible, with an Indian agent at hand to supply their most pressing needs.

Long after much of this mischief had been done, and when Indians who lived near white men had begun to lose their noble characteristics, the white woman appeared on the scene. In most cases, she
pulled her dainty skirts aside and refused to associate with her bronze-coloured sisters. She taught her children to despise the Indians and forbade them to go near the camps. She forgot that there are good Indians and bad Indians—just as there are good whites and bad whites—and she professed to believe that every Indian home was a hotbed of vile disease. She even thought that swarthy complexions and weather-stained garments were necessarily dirty, because they were unlike her own fair skin and snowy clothes. It was sad, too, to see her attitude towards the white men who had settled down with Indian wives in the days when there were no white women in the North; she probably resented the fact that any white man should wed an Indian bride! Most cruel of all was the white woman's contempt for the little "half-breed" children to be found in many an Indian camp. She forgot the suffering and sadness that white men had brought to the now abandoned mothers of these little ones. Perhaps she even forgot the tender pity of the Master Who once said:

"Suffer the little children to come unto me, and forbid them not."

In her blindness, the white woman persuaded her menfolk to despise the very people whose exploitation made them rich. Such a sad state of affairs could not continue long without kindling the indignation of thoughtful people.

When the public conscience was at least pricking—if not fully aroused—efforts were made to right some of the wrongs that had been committed by white men and their women-folk. Missionaries were placed on the Reserves to teach the People about their Saviour and help them in their misery. Boarding schools were founded to train young Indians for earning their own livings along white lines. Day-schools were started on the Reserves to give many more children a chance of learning to read and write. Certain government regulations were made to prevent some of the exploitation of the Indians by unscrupulous traders. Some white women even allowed Indian girls to become their maids, and occasionally they consented to worship with their Indian sisters on a very special occasion! Of course, they did not really treat them as sisters, but they were genuinely glad to make clothes for Indian children or to contribute to the support of Indian Missions. It just did not strike them that the dignified, stoical People had once been fine, self-supporting folk who roamed the land in freedom, long before the first white man set eyes on the "Indians" in this country.
Mercifully, however, the public conscience is at last coming to life. Church and government officials alike are investigating the whole situation and giving careful and critical consideration to their own handling of Indian affairs. Health authorities are, at least mildly, concerned about matters of hygiene, if only for the sake of the white people with whom the Indians come in contact. Some educationists are questioning the advisability of educating Indian children on ordinary white lines; others are coming forward with schemes for developing native handicrafts or giving specialized training to fit the children for the way in which they normally earn their own living. Others propose the establishment of centres where mothers may learn child care and cookery. White mothers are beginning to realize that Indian mothers have feelings too, and they know now that the poor health of undernourished half-breed children in our schools is a menace to their own children's health. People who pack bales are no longer saying, "Anything will do for the Indians!" They realize that Indian women have invariably fewer facilities for washing and mending clothes, so they deal with dirty and torn clothing before they pack it. They also include in their bales the kind of things that are really useful for women who wander from place to place, or little articles that are a boon to sick people living in dire poverty. Some women now are a little ashamed that their children have so many luxuries when Indian mothers "across the track" have nothing for their little ones.

Missionaries are practising more than ever in their daily life, the Gospel that they preach, and are trying to help the Indians regain the old independence that characterized their attitude before the white man reached their hunting grounds.

Much still remains to be done, and the work is urgently needed, because the Indian population of Canada is actually increasing and will eventually menace the life of the community, if it is allowed to drift on in its distress. Everyone in Canada should make it his or her business to study Indian problems; to give wholehearted support to the missionaries who are working on behalf of this sadly oppressed race; and, wherever possible, to give a kindly word and a helping hand to the friendly folk who have often been...
wronged by their presumably Christian Brothers and sisters. Not all traders exploit the Indians, and not all white people are hard and inconsiderate; but most of those who read these words will admit that there is much room for improvement in the present situation. The essential feature of our Indian reconstruction policy must be the effort to give the native race the kind of help that will enable it to be both happy and independent while it is leading the type of life for which it is best suited. There are two ways in which you can immediately render assistance to these patient Indian folk. First, contribute to the missionary apportionment of your local Church, in order that much-needed work among the Indians may be continued, and secondly, treat every Indian with whom you have dealings just as you think Christ would treat him if He were in your place. Most of us still need to pray the prayer expressed in Kipling's words:

"Teach us the strength that cannot seek,
By deed or thought to hurt the weak;
That under Thee we may possess
Man's strength to comfort man's distress.

Teach us delight in simple things,

Dear Sir:

We have, in the northern part of this Province, a school known as Big Eddy School, which is located within a reasonable distance of the two Indian Schools which operate in The Pas area. The school population of Big Eddy School is composed entirely of half-breed children, all of whom speak Cree for the most part, and the teacher going into this district faces a very definite handicap in this regard. The children from Big Eddy School, being half-breed children, do not attempt in any way to mix with the white children, and they seek their companionship from the children who are attending the Indian Schools in the area.

Our Official Trustee at Big Eddy has discussed the matter with Mr. Lovell, the Indian Agent at that point, and with Mr. Waller, who is a teacher in one of the schools, and all three seem to be agreed that the best interests of the children would be served were the children from Big Eddy School to be allowed to attend either or both of the Indian Schools of the area. They seem to feel that if this were possible, the scheme would work out to the ultimate advantage of both sides if the present Indian population is not too large. We understand that Mr. Lovell has made a check on this and finds that conditions indicate that there would be ample accommodation for the children of Big Eddy School in the Indian Schools.

Mr. Bateman, our Official Trustee at Big Eddy, has talked with Mr. Waller on this matter and it appears that none of the children would have over two miles to travel to attend the Indian School. Mr. Waller further feels that the attendance of the children of Big Eddy School at the Indian School would have a very definite effect upon the attendance of his own students, since the students from Big Eddy and from the Indian School mix outside of school hours, and there is apparently a very noticeable tendency for the students of the Indian School to remain outside of school to promote the mixing. It is felt, therefore, that could they be brought together during the school day, the general attendance within the school would be improved. There is the additional factor that Mr. Waller speaks Cree fluently, and this of course gives him a decided advantage in gaining the confidence of the younger students in the class, an advantage which the teacher which we would send into Big Eddy School would definitely not have.

The point upon which we would like to make inquiry at this time is as to whether or not it is possible to enter into some arrangement with the
Dominion Government for the attendance of the children from Big Eddy School at one of the Indian Schools in The Pas area. The advantages to be gained therefrom have been set forth above, and as previously stated, those who are on the ground and know the children of both schools, seem to feel that the arrangement would work to the advantage of all concerned. If such an arrangement could be made, it would have to be understood by this Department, of course, that the plan could only operate so long as there was sufficient accommodation over and above what was needed for the children of the Indian Schools.

We understand that a plan of like nature has been in operation in other parts of the Dominion and has met with every success. On this basis we would respectfully solicit your consideration of this matter, and we shall await your advice on same.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Brisbin:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of September 15, in which you submit, for our consideration, a number of suggestions with respect to the operation of the Big Eddy and Pas Indian Day Schools.

I personally can see no objection whatever to the attendance of halfbreed children at either or both of these schools. Unless the schools are unusually large, however, it is difficult for me to convince myself that the children now enrolled at the Big Eddy Public School can be accommodated at our schools. Our records here suggest that we have at this date an enrolment at Big Eddy of 30 and an enrolment of 24 at The Pas. The average attendance at both these schools, of course, appears to be low, but I am naturally anxious not to base my decision on the fact that attendance at our schools will remain unsatisfactory in the future.

We have, throughout the Dominion, a limited number of Indian schools at which instruction is provided for white pupils. The number of white children at such schools, however, is very limited. It is just possible that we might undertake, by way of experiment, in The Pas area, a program somewhat along the lines you suggest. Halfbreed children might be provided with accommodation and instruction at our schools, on the understanding that the annual per capita costs, which are no doubt very low, would be borne by the Big Eddy Public School District. On the other hand, it might be deemed expedient to provide these pupils with a worthwhile course of vocational instruction and a man employed who would provide this instruction -

Scott Bateman, the Public School Inspector for the district, came into the office yesterday and brought with him a copy of Mr. Hoey's letter to Mr. Brisbin, dated the 21st ultimo and also a letter from Mr. Brisbin to Mr. Bateman in connection with half-breed children of the Big Eddy Settlement attending our Indian Day Schools on the Pas Reserve.

The matter was thoroughly discussed and it was decided to make the following recommendations.

That as many half-breed children as can be comfortably accommodated be allowed to attend the Big Eddy School, preferably the younger children as they would not have far to walk. The half-breed children who could not be accommodated at the Big Eddy School be allowed to attend the Pas Day School. They would have to travel about 2½ to three miles to do this, but this is not any greater than a large proportion of the white children attending country schools have to travel.

That the half-breed children attending the Indian schools be provided with books, stationery and also biscuits the same as the Indian children. It would not work satisfactorily any other way as one could not expect the teacher to give one child a book and provide him with stationery and also give him biscuits at midday, unless they all got the same.

The cost of the service our Department would be rendering to the Province and the cost of the supplies provided could be met by a per capita charge to the province. It would cost the Provincial Department of Education to keep a school open only eight months, at least $500.00 and probably more. I think the tuition and supplies could be provided for less than that under the arrangement suggested above.

I cannot recommend starting any vocational training in the schools at the present time. I think it would be better if we tried the above mentioned plan out for a year before we do anything further. If everything works out satisfactorily then the matter of vocational training could be considered.

You will notice that our plan does not interfere with the Indian children in any way and I believe sufficient room can be found at both schools for all the half-breed children who are likely to attend.

The responsibility of seeing that the half-breed children attend school regularly should be the duty of the Provincial authorities.

Regarding the Half-breed Settlement at Big Eddy. This is situated close to the Reserve Settlement. In fact one can hardly tell where the Indians' settlement ends and the Half-breed settlement begins. The Half-breeds and Indians are racially the same people, live the same mode of life and cannot be distinguished from each other.

The half-breeds, at the present time, are getting little or no education. This will make it difficult for them to earn a living, bound to cause trouble and expense in the future and have a detrimental effect upon the Indians.

I do not think the enrolment at either the Big Eddy or the Pas Day School will be as good this year as it was last, as quite a number of children from the Pas Reserve have gone to Elkhorn Residential School. Quite a number of the Indians are now away from the Reserve fishing, lumbering and trapping and their families are with them in many cases.

Dear Mr. Glen:

It has been noted with considerable interest in our Department that a joint Committee of the House to survey all matters related to the welfare of the Indian population in Canada has been appointed. The hope is frequently expressed that as a result of the study made by this Committee, recommendations will be made that will be of value to Provincial Departments of Education in their efforts to bring improved educational services to the non-Indian residents of the northern localities. Your action in having the committee appointed is well regarded. We are prepared to offer any information that we may be able to give in respect to communities where, by reason of a mixed population, the problem involves provincial responsibilities to the end that mutually advantageous arrangements may be worked out.

Inspectors of our Department frequently cite instances where joint action by the Department of Indian Affairs and the Provincial Department of Education would result in improved service to both groups. One specific illustration is the Big Eddy District close to The Pas. This school district is semi-organized only and the school building we have there is in poor condition. We hesitate to rebuild it into a standard classroom because only 400 yards away, the Indian School is located much more favorably and with good grounds. There are about thirty half-breed children and thirty Treaty Indian children resident in the district. Our Divisional School Inspector, Mr. Bateman, strongly urges the enlargement of your school building by adding a second room so that it can accommodate all of the sixty children in the district. This, he believes, would make for better understanding among the people, a better school service could be offered, and the status of education locally would be raised - something that is sorely needed at present in this particular community. The matter has been discussed with your Departmental official, Mr. Lovall, in The Pas, who also recommends co-operative action if a suitable understanding could be reached.

It would be necessary to provide for -

1. The appointment of a local board to administer the affairs of the school that could be made up of one member appointed by our Department, one by your Department, and a third who

... might
might possibly be a representative of the church - the selection to be mutually agreed upon.

2. The division of the costs of operating the school on a per capita basis. The operating costs could include an agreed upon amount to offset capital charges occasioned by the enlargement of your present building. In this connection, an arrangement that would place the ownership of the building itself in one or other of the two departments would, I believe, be more satisfactory than to attempt a joint ownership plan. In this particular instance, your Department already has a serviceable unit and it would seem to be more practical to have your Department retain the building ownership and include in the operating charges a sum that would carry the item of its enlargement costs. There may be other cases where it would be desirable to have the building ownership rest with the Provincial Government.

We should also give consideration to the type of education to offer in these special schools. I believe you or some member of your Departmental staff will be interested in reading a special report prepared last winter by Inspector Bateman covering the general situation in the educational field in northern Manitoba. There is strong support for the necessity of providing children, both Indian and Half-breed, in these localities with a type of education adapted to the environment in which they live. By combining our efforts where it is practical and sensible to do so, we can expect to cover the field more adequately by employing specially selected teachers and providing suitable equipment. By attempting to do it through separate organizations, our total costs are certain to run up much higher.

Perhaps you would be good enough to refer this proposal regarding Big Eddy School District to a member of your staff with instructions to examine the possibilities it has as an experimental test. I would like very much at some convenient time, to have the benefit of your own views as to ways and means by which the educational offerings in these mixed communities of Indians and Half-breeds may be better adapted to meet their special needs.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) J. C. Dryden

Dear Mr. Dryden:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of August 8th, and also a report submitted to you by Mr. Scott Bateman sent forward therewith.

It is unnecessary to state that the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch and myself are deeply interested in the subject matter of these communications.

You will be interested to learn that it is our intention to seek authority in the revised Indian Act to enter into agreements with Provincial Departments of Education for the joint operation of day schools in remote regions of the Dominion. It is not anticipated that we shall experience difficulty with respect to the cost of establishing such schools in cooperation with the provinces or the payment of the operating costs. To say, however, experience difficulty due to the fact that the Dominion Government, under the provisions of the Indian Act, is not in a position to exercise authority with respect to the attendance of pupils at schools other than Indians, or with respect to the courses of study that should be provided for white pupils. In this connection, it would appear that the Provincial Departments are in a somewhat similar position insofar as Indians are concerned. You will readily appreciate, therefore, that any agreement entered into would have to be entered into in the absence of opposition and by mutual consent. Until consideration can be given to this matter, it is our intention to have an official of the Indian Affairs Branch undertake a number of educational surveys in areas such as the Big Sky area in northern Manitoba and in a number of outlying districts where the children of school age appear to be evenly divided between Indians and half-breeds.

In this particular instance, your department already has a serviceable unit and it would seem to be more practical to have your Department retain the building ownership and include in the operating charges a sum that would carry the item of its enlargement costs. There may be other cases where it would be desirable to have the building ownership rest with the Provincial Government.

We should also give consideration to the type of education to offer in these special schools. I believe you or some member of your departmental staff will be interested in reading a special report prepared last winter by Inspector Bateman covering the general situation in the educational field in northern Manitoba. There is strong support for the necessity of providing children, both Indian and Half-breed, in these localities with a type of education adapted to the environment in which they live. By combining our efforts where it is practical and sensible to do so, we can expect to cover the field more adequately by employing specially selected teachers and providing suitable equipment. By attempting to do it through separate organizations, our total costs are certain to run up much higher.

Perhaps you would be good enough to refer this proposal regarding Big Eddy School District to a member of your staff with instructions to examine the possibilities it has as an experimental test. I would like very much at some convenient time, to have the benefit of your own views as to ways and means by which the educational offerings in these mixed communities of Indians and Half-breeds may be better adapted to meet their special needs.

Yours truly,

(Sgd.) J.C. Dryden - Minister of Education.
IV - POINTS RELATIVE TO THE EDUCATIONAL SITUATION IN ISOLATED AREAS OF THE NORTH

1. Away from the steel, the great majority of those without educational facilities are the Indians and the Half-breeds. Throughout this discussion it should be noted that an Indian is a Treaty Indian, a ward of the Dominion Government; while a Half-breed is any person who has any proportion of Indian blood but is not a Treaty Indian. It is therefore evident that many Half-breeds are by heritage really Indians, but since they are not on the Treaty lists they are classified as Half-breeds. There are many cases of blood brothers, both of whom were Treaty at one time, but one commuted his treaty money and so lost his standing as a Treaty Indian, while the other remained Treaty. The one would then be classed as a Half-breed and his education would be the charge of the Province, while the other would be classed as Treaty, and he a charge in all respects of the Dominion.

2. In general terms neither the Indian nor the Half-breed is accepted by the white man on anything approaching equal terms.

3. The Indian and the Half-breed have points in common apart from blood ties. They fish the same lakes, trap the same grounds, live in the same type of home, eat the same food, think the same thoughts, worship at the same churches, suffer from the same diseases - and attend different schools (if any), the one Provincial, the other Dominion.

4. Both groups are essentially nomadic. When the mood strikes them, they go. This is partly due to racial inheritance, partly economic necessity. Frequently an Indian or Half-breed on a regular job will get the urge to go somewhere, and he is likely to leave immediately, without waiting to collect his pay or to arrange for mechanical transport. At certain periods of the year he and his family leave for the fishing grounds or the trap-line, and may be away from their home point for several months. Their movements are generally within a circumscribed area and they have what might be termed a permanent address.

5. The Indians may send their children to Boarding Schools operated by the various churches. These schools are not held in high esteem as they take the children away from their families. Contrary to the belief current among Whites, Indians can and do cherish affection for their children. I have frequently seen weeping and wailing when the time came for separation of parents and children. The Boarding Schools and Day Schools operated by the churches are charged with exercising religious interference. I am sure the charge is well-founded. In the first instance the schools are opened in a spirit of missionary zeal. If there is to be no religious influence exerted, why do the churches operate the schools? They have served... a purpose
a purpose in the past, and served it well, but they are now an anachronism.

Too frequently the product of the Boarding School is a problem to himself and to the community from which he hails. He has been away from his normal surroundings during his formative years, while his mates at home were busily learning the traditional Indian skills essential to making a livelihood in the bush. On his return he may speak English fluently and be well versed in many of the white man's ways. He may have learned much about raising crops and stock, and he may have a sound grounding in mathematics. But he cannot compete with the White man in the White man's enterprises - he is in fact an outcast in white circles, his position somewhat analogous to that of the Negro in the Southern States - and he knows nothing of fishing, trapping or hunting, so is unable to compete with his own race. Outside the White Man's sphere of activity his English may serve him well in making a fine speech, but he may not be proficient in Cree; his crops are not found in the field, but on the lakes, marshes and traplines; his stock consists of beaver and muskrats, not cows, sheep or hogs; and his mathematics is useless above the most elementary level. It is not unusual, therefore, the discover that the Indian who writes a fine hand or turns a polished phrase becomes a renegade and ne'er-do-well.

6. The Day School student lives at home, maintains contact with his future surroundings and methods of livelihood, learning as much out of school as he does in it. If the school is free from Church influence, his whole day is devoted to non-religious phases of education. This is important because such schools in the outlying districts cannot hope to hold their students for the extended periods which prevail outside, either on the basis of the number of days in the school year, nor on the basis of the number of school years during which attendance may be maintained. In either case, the payment of Family Allowances may exert an influence yet to be assessed.

7. Because the Indian problem and the Half-breed problem are indivisible the Dominion and the Province have seen fit to enter into a co-operative agreement with regard to the development of the fur resources of Northern Manitoba. In this instance, the agreement calls for a division of the costs of initiating, administering and executing certain fur rehabilitation measures. Surely, if the guaranteeing of a livelihood to these two groups is part and parcel of the same problem, then is not the guaranteeing of suitable education to the same groups a joint responsibility, to be jointly undertaken and jointly financed. (The agreement referred to above is the Dominion-Provincial Fur Agreement, dated March 23rd, 1945. It is a document worth reading if only as an indication of the mutual benefits which may accrue through a policy of mutual action as between Province and Dominion.)

New Plan Will Combine Indian Schools in West

Winnipeg, April 13 (CP) — Indian, on a per capita basis, for each Metis and Metis children in Northern child attendance, the Manitoba Government embark upon a new educational program this year designed to remove any suggestion of half-breed settlement on the racial discrimination and also fitting the reservation for more realistic and more economical from The Pas. No Metis schooling has been provided here for nearly five years due to a lack of teachers.

The program, reported in Ottawa yesterday by federal Indian Affairs, will have Indian and Metis children attending the same schools in future, instead of following the previous practice of segregation.

The plan is one which Manitoba has had under consideration for some time, Provincial Education Minister J. C. Dryden said here today.

Briefly, the joint education plan will mean this: In the past the Dominion Government was responsible for all Indian affairs, including education, and all Indian schools were established under federal authority. The Metis, on the other hand, came under provincial jurisdiction, and their schools were province-sponsored.

"One criticism of that mode of operations," said Mr. Dryden, "was that the Indian and Metis children in the northern part of the province played together, ate together and hunted together, when it came to school attendance, they were compelled to go to separate institutions."

Will Build Schools

Under the new plan, the Indian Affairs branch has agreed that in areas where there are no schools and there is a preponderance of Indians, the federal government will build a school. The Manitoba Government will reimburse the branch...

NEW EDUCATIONAL EXPERIMENT

North to Have First Indian-Metis School

(Special to The Winnipeg Tribune)

THE PAS, Man., Aug. 20—First project in Manitoba by which Indian and Metis children will be educated in the same school, with expenses borne jointly by the province and the Department of Indian Affairs, the day school at Big Eddy, five miles from The Pas, is being enlarged and modified.

Work is scheduled to be completed in time for the fall term in September.

The school also represents an experimental project to determine feasibility of the new plan of joint education which may have far reaching effects in smaller settlements throughout the north. Hitherto each settlement needed sufficient Indian children to provide one school and Metis children to provide another, with the result that many useless and possibly unnecessary schools were built.

In preparation for the start of the school term—which means one year far from home for the Indian students from isolated settlements—in northern Manitoba—an aerial school bus is now transporting about 140 pupils to Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, in northern Saskatchewan.

Prior to the use of the aircraft parents brought their children hundreds of miles by canoe to the long established mission school, but now goodbyes are said at the homes of the children—with stoicism shown by both parents and children. The students range in age from eight to 16 years and learn handicrafts and basic trades as well as literacy at Fr Peirler's School.

The new plan stipulates that the majority of children shall determine whether the school will be built by the province or the Indian Department and the majority will have their tuition paid by the responsible authority.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

You will recall our discussion in October or 1946 in connection with the operation of the Big Eddy School near The Pas. The understanding which we reached on that occasion was to combine the educational work for the Indian and Half-Breed children in the one unit. Progress along this line appears to be satisfactory and, while we chose to regard this move at Big Eddy as being experimental, the practical advantage of following this plan at other points is evident.

The case of South Indian Lake, a settlement about 150 miles North of Wabden, is being brought to our attention quite frequently. The school population within a mile and a half radius of the central point is reported as being 61 Indian children and 25 Half-Breed children.

It is an isolated community and if a building is to be erected, supplies would have to go in by winter freight within the next six weeks.

I would be pleased to have the views of your Department on the advisability of providing the people there with a school. We are ready to co-operate in sharing in the costs of operating the school and to render such assistance as we can in its administration.

Trusting you will let us have the benefit of the opinion of your officials on this proposal at an early date, I am,

Yours very sincerely,

J.G. Dryden,
Minister of Education.

Memorandum:

Major MacKay

Re: Miss E.B. Montgomery - Big Eddy Indian Day School

CONFIDENTIAL

Please find attached a self-explanatory report received from Mr. Indian Superintendent Law of The Pas, Manitoba, with regard to injuries received by one of my two teachers at the Big Eddy School.

This is a joint school operated for both the Indians and half-breeds at Big Eddy which is an Indian Reserve located immediately adjacent to a half-breed colony.

You will note that one of the half-breeds has attacked Miss Montgomery and that in all likelihood this man will be convicted of an attempt of rape.

From your own field experience you will realize the seriousness of this situation. It is my feeling that Mr. Indian Superintendent Law should be instructed to see that this man is prosecuted to the fullest extent possible. Although he is not an Indian, he did attack a teacher employed by this Department, and I feel that it is essential that he be jailed for the maximum term.

There have been a few previous instances of this nature, but we have usually not been able to locate the
man or men involved. For the general protection and security of the female teachers employed in my schools, I feel that every such instance must be treated as a serious offence and the maximum penalty called for.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Sir:

I wired you yesterday as follows:

"Due to injuries to Miss E.B. Montgomery, Saturday, November 13th, Stop. One room at Big Eddy School will be closed until she is able to return next week."

Believing that you should know the facts in this connection I would like to advise you that Miss Montgomery was attacked by one of the half-breeds from Big Eddy, on Saturday night, November 13th. As she is the dispenser of drugs for that community she frequently has calls from men at night, so let this man in without hesitation.

Apparently he attacked her and she struggled with him both inside and outside the house. It was several hours, most of which was spent outside the house, before she was able to free herself and run for assistance. During this time she was badly bruised about the body and face, and her feet were frozen. She finally reached a neighbor's home and a message was sent to the Doctor. She is at present being cared for at the Doctor's home.

The R.C.M.P. picked this man up the next day, and we hope he will be convicted on an attempt of rape.

I interviewed Miss Montgomery as regards to her returning to the school, and she said she would be willing to do so as soon as the Doctor approved. As she will be called as a witness when this case comes up, likely at the spring assizes, I feel it would be wise to leave her here, for the full school term.

I would appreciate very much hearing from you if you have any further instructions or suggestions in this case.

Your obedient servant,

A.M. Law,
Supt., Indian Agency.

MEMORANDUM

Col. Neary
Superintendent of Education

Your memorandum of November 20th enclosing copy of a letter from E. Law, Superintendent, Indian Agency, The Pas, Manitoba, regarding Miss E. B. Montgomery - Big Eddy Indian Day School, has been considered carefully.

It is noted that a charge against the person responsible for this attack may be laid under the Criminal Code and also that the suspect is a half-breed and therefore not of Indian status.

In these circumstances it is presumed that proceedings will be taken in the usual way by the authorities responsible for the administration of justice in the Province of Manitoba. There does not appear to be any action which this Branch could take in the matter. It is agreed, however, that the offence is most heinous and great sympathy is felt for the victim. It is certainly considered that members of the staff devoting their lives to the education of the Indian people, should be protected in every way possible.

This Branch of course cannot assume any responsibility for any expense involved in Criminal Code enforcement which is the responsibility and duty of the provincial authorities. If, however, there is any way in which we can assist in connection with the securing of evidence and Indian witnesses, the matter will be considered if the Indian Superintendent will submit a further report with additional details.

Please advise him accordingly.

Acting Director.

Big Eddy Indian Day School
Ref. your 203-11 (136) of June 15

The Department is prepared to transfer Mrs. Olds from the Fairford to the Big Eddy School effective 1 September 1949, in accordance with your recommendations. I presume that Miss Montgomery could be transferred to the Fairford School at the same time. If Mrs. Olds has a large family, then she would probably have to board in The Pas and travel daily to the school by bus.

Bernard F. Neely,

Sir,

I have the honor to report that the cheque for the Teacher at Big Eddy Day School amounting to $202.50 was received.

Miss Cook wishes to know if she is to receive this sum quarterly in future, as in the past, she was only receiving $100 per quarter.

I have the honor to be, Sir,

Your obedient Servant,

[Signature]
Indian Agent.

Assistant Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, August 1, 1922.

Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 26th ultimo, I beg to say that Miss Cook began duties as Teacher at the Big Eddy School last September, at a salary of $450 a year. As is usual with new teachers, she was only paid for the September quarter, 1921, for the number of days she actually taught the school, and she therefore received the sum of $22.50. For both the December and March quarters she was paid one quarter of her yearly salary, or $112.50 for each quarter.

As the school year in Indian day schools begins on September first and ends on June 30th, and as her June quarter return showed that she had taught during the period she was in charge of this school the required number of days, the Department paid her for the June quarter the balance of her yearly salary, which amounted to $302.50. If she continues in charge of this school, she will be paid at the same rate as previously, viz.: $450 per annum.

The method of payment of bonus to teachers of Indian day schools has not yet been decided upon. When a decision is reached, the bonus due Miss Cook for the quarter ending June 30th, last, will be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

J. W. Waddy, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6228, File 502-3, part 1)
Ottawa, October 14, 1930.

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Lordship the Bishop of Brandon has advised the Department that Miss L. Miller, teacher of the Big Eddy Indian Day School has tendered her resignation, to take effect December 31st, next. His Lordship has nominated the services of Mrs. Charles Morris, wife of the missionary on the reserve, as teacher to succeed Miss Miller. He states Mrs. Morris is a qualified teacher and has had previous experience.

This Department has approved of the appointment of Mrs. Morris, with salary at the rate of $60 per teaching month. She will begin duties on or about the first of January, next. We have informed His Lordship and Mr. Commissioner Graham, Regina, of the approval granted for the appointment of Mrs. Morris. I have to request that you will give her every assistance you can upon her taking up duties at this school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. G. Tweedell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Extract from Diary

Trip to Prince Albert

June 4 Started from The Pas at 8 a.m. bound for Prince Albert to purchase and transport lumber supplies. Mr. David Ross, Joseph Buck, John Conant, Abraham, Isaiah Buck, Surveyor.

Fair wind all day. Camped at 10:30 P.M.

5 Started at 4:30 A.M. Camped at 9:46

6 Blowing a gale. Could not venture out. Horace Belanger came for us at 6:17 P.M. and took us into Cumberland with his steamboat. Wind was so high we could not cross the lake until 5 P.M. Horace took us in tow with his steamboat and

8 Landed at Sturgeon River at 3 P.M. Rowed till dark

9 High wind & heavy rain did not start to subside till dark. Camped at dark

10 Started at 5 A.M. Good wind. Camped at dark

11 Started at 5 A.M. Rowed & tracked till dark

12 Started at 5 A.M. Tracked till dark

13 Arrived at Fort La Corne at 7 P.M.

14 Men went on with the boat I drove overland from La Corne to Prince Albert. Arrived there at 10 P.M.

15 to 21. Making purchases and superintending the building of flat boats.

22 Loading up flat boats

23 to 24. Visiting in the Country

25 Started for The Pas at 9 A.M. And with eight days uneventful run we arrived at The Pas on 2nd July. Got unloaded and paid off the men.

Joseph Conant

Sir,

I have the honour to inform you that some years ago the bearer, Mr. James Settee, Jr., was my Interpreter and canoe man at Lake of the Woods. While carrying a load over a portage he fell backwards and got ruptured and Dr. Hanson, father of the present Doctor of Rat Portage attended him and adjusted a truss on him but now his truss is worn out and is useless and he desires to get a new one which I would recommend be given him. He has been in the service of the Department as School teacher for twenty-eight years having taught latterly at Cumberland House and now he is retiring from the service he wishes the Department to be good enough to pay his expenses from Cumberland to St. Peter's where he intends in future to reside as that is the Band to which he belongs.
