Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the repairs required to the teacher's residence in connection with the Big Eddy Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that, if the Church Authorities can obtain the services of an unmarried teacher, you may arrange to have the necessary repairs made to the one-story log building near the school, in order to supply suitable living quarters for the teacher's use. We note that you estimate the cost of these repairs would be approximately $50. You may also arrange, if a teacher is secured, to have the closets built at The Pas and take out any surplus in a suitable position at the school. You should not undertake any of this work until a teacher is engaged, when you may expend an amount not exceeding $125 in fitting up the building as living quarters for the teacher and in erecting the closets.

We note that, if the services of a married teacher are required, it would be necessary to carry out considerably more repairs in order to provide living accommodation. In that event, any repairs undertaken should be done as cheaply as possible. You should purchase any material required, after obtaining competitive prices, and arrange for the labour in doing the work. You will keep proper time sheets for the labour employed and forward certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering any expenditure incurred.

We note by your letter of the above date that you have written Mr. Alfred H. Chenaux and informed him that the Church Authorities do not desire to recommend his application for the position of teacher at this school. We hope they will be in a position to nominate a suitable teacher at an early date.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honor to report that I visited the Big Eddy Day School on the 9th and on the 13th inst., and found everything going fine. The average attendance is over 30.

I put in the new blackboards and got the place put in good shape generally. The medical officer was with me and he ordered screen windows put on at once so the windows could be left open, they were closed to keep out the mosquitoes. I got the screens and put them on myself yesterday and enclose the account, I trust this is satisfactory.

The supplies ordered on requisition dated May 15th arrived, but were not as ordered. The Stationery Dept substituted Canadian Readers Book 1 for Gages Phonic Primer, 2 doz. Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his inspection of the Big Eddy Indian Day School, states that the following equipment is required:

- Wire mat for the front door,
- More hooks for the wraps,
- Sheet of tin to place under the stove.

If you consider that the equipment mentioned is necessary, you may arrange for the purchase of a wire mat, a number of hooks and a sheet of tin to place under the stove.

You should look into the Inspector's suggestion regarding the desks, and, if possible, arrange to have them securely fastened to the floor.

No unnecessary expenditure should be incurred in the above purchases or in carrying out the Inspector's suggestion regarding the desks, and properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred.

Prince Albert, Sask., Sept. 6, 1926.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have just returned to Prince Albert after a long round of the Indian missions of the North.

BIG EDDY DAY SCHOOL

I had a large deputation of the Indians including the Chief and all the councillors urging me to apply to the Department for a new school to replace the old log thing that Miss Millan has at Big Eddy. From all accounts the rain gets in and the mud smells badly, besides seeping out continually, and altogether the building is disputable. All agreed with the missionary that Miss Millan's work was thoroughly good and clearly her influence is most marked on the Indians as well as thoroughly good teaching work with the children. She seems to put her whole heart into the work and I would strongly urge that a new school like Humberstone's should be built there. I ought to add that the opening of these two day schools there has had a very marked effect on the whole Devon Mission, it was a good stroke of work when those schools were opened.

G. E. Saskatchewan.
Bishop.

Dear Sir:

At a Meeting of the Executive Committee of the Diocese of Saskatchewan, held on the 17th inst., I was asked to again bring to your notice the matter of the Erection of a new Indian Day School building at Big Eddy, on the Pas Reserve, concerning which a letter was written to you by the Right Rev. G.E. Lloyd, Bishop of Saskatchewan and acknowledged by you on Sep. 27th, 1926, No. 128-15-5.

The urgency of the need for the new building is shown from the Copy of letter, dated January 18, 1927, received from the Rev. A. Fraser of the Devon Mission, The Pas, who is in charge of the District in which Big Eddy is situated and which reads as follows:

"Having made a careful survey of the School Building situated at the Big Eddy, on the Pas Reserve (Indian) I have come to the conclusion that it is very unfit for further use as a School House.

The building itself has been in use for thirty years or more, built of logs, shingled roof and ceiled ceiling about 7ft. 6in., possible cost when built about $200.00.

The foundation logs are badly decayed, and the others are in poor shape; it is built like many other buildings right on the ground sills being set on the earth.

It has a very mouldy smell, especially in damp weather, and further, it has not the required air-space for a number of thirty pupils and is very unsanitary.

I hereby recommend that the Department of Indian Affairs be asked to replace the old School house by a new frame building, Standard Dimensions to accommodate thirty (30) children.

The cost, complete with furnishings, would be in the neighbourhood of $2000.00. No time should be lost as we require the building to..."

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF MISS L. MILLER, TEACHER OF THE BIG EDDY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL, FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDING MARCH 31st, 1928.

For the last two or three years the Indians, besides ourselves, have tried to get a new school. This is not sanitary. We really felt we were to have one this last year, and as we did not, the Indians have got discouraged. They were taking the greatest interest in the school work. I had to discharge nearly all my big boys and girls. Those who are left feel the loss. There are many who should be at school, but are forbidden on account of air space. Most of the day, winter and summer, we have to keep our door open, besides the stove pipe is only a few inches above our heads. The heat is awful sometimes. The children are very eager to learn and are doing well. I had one boy who passed from Grade 1 to Grade VII in three years, but he was discharged although he wishes to go on.

September 12th, 1928.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just returned from a long round of the Indian missions of the North and I want specially to bring to your attention the matter of the Big Eddy School at The Pas, with Miss MacMillan as the teacher.

You will remember that this is the old school at the upper end of the Devon Mission. The building in which the school is being held is a very old log building past all repair. It was built about thirty-five years ago without any foundation and the smell of rotten wood makes the atmosphere always musty and disagreeable for both teacher and pupils. The old ceiling is very low and the building has been condemned several times as unsanitary.

Your Inspector visited it the other day and ordered ten or fifteen children to be sent home and the number reduced to twenty because of the confined air space. The Agent has been spoken to several times about the condition of this building and he says that it only needs the application from the Bishop.

There are thirty-five children around this school of which thirty were actually in attendance when the Health Inspector prohibited more than twenty.

A new school building to hold thirty-five children with a residence for the teacher is urgently needed, and I sincerely hope that you may be able to sanction this so that it may be ready for use before the New Year. It has been badly needed for some time past.

Yours very faithfully,

BIG REDDY DAY SCHOOL.

This school comes under the Church of England who have Miss Millen as teacher. I understand she has taught for many years and apparently is doing good work.

The register calls for 22 pupils, but only 15 were present, 7 boys and 8 girls. The grades range from 1 to 6 and the work examined was good.

The classroom was exceptionally clean and tidy and I believe Miss Millen takes great pride in keeping the school as bright and cheerful as possible.

The school building is built of logs and sided up on the inside. The ceiling is low and yet the room was well aired on the day of inspection. Miss Millen claimed the place was easily heated, even in the severe weather.

Undoubtedly a new building will be needed here before many years if the school is to be continued. I would, however, point out that the MacKay Boarding School is not more than two to three miles away from any of these Indian homes and as they are practically all Church of England people, it would appear unnecessary to erect a new school, especially if the boarding school can accommodate the children.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Sir:-

BIG EDDY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

This school is in charge of Miss M. Millen. The roll calls for 25 children. I found 18 present. The attendance at this school is good, the average for September being 19.15. The grades are as follows:

- Grade I - 8
- II - 7
- IV - 3
- V - 3

The children

BIG EDDY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

The children appeared fairly well along in the work examined, but I found them very reluctant in answering any questions, and it was practically impossible to hear their voices across the room.

A new school was erected this year, and the building is in A1 condition.

The children are provided with individual drinking cups, but as they have no drinking fountain, they are obliged to dip these cups into the pail which contains the drinking water. It would be well if a small fountain were provided.

This school is without either flag or flagpole.

Inspector Hamilton's Report on Schools, The Pas Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham,

I have the honour to submit the following report on the schools inspected on The Pas Reserve, between November 4th and the 12th, 1930.

BIG EDDY INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

This school is in charge of Miss Millen who has spent many years teaching Indian children. I understand Miss Millen is retiring at the close of the December quarter.

The roll calls for 28 pupils, and I found eighteen present, 8 boys and 10 girls. The children were fairly well clothed, but were somewhat untidy, as though little attention had been given to their personal appearance. A large number of children were suffering from severe colds.

The grades are arranged as follows:

| Grade | Number |
|-------|--------|
| I     | 12     |
| II    | 2      |
| III   | 4      |
| V     | 3      |
| VII   | 1      |

The children appear to understand their work, and in most cases speak out well, at least, much better than in either the Pas Day School or the Mackay Residential School.

The attendance for the last quarter was 18.4, and so far this quarter, it is equally as good.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,

Sir:

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No. 128-15-5 of the 27th ultimo, re Closets and Well for the Big Eddy Indian Day School, The Pas, I may say I have considered the well proposition, and intend including this in our next estimates, as it would require a considerable expenditure.

A Well, Pump, Cribbing and Pump House would cost approximately $200.00.

The children have carried water so far, and I think they might carry on for this year;

Re Closets, one of the ones in use is fairly good, and with some repairs and paint would do. The other one should be moved to another site repaired and painted. I should say this could be done for $25.00 which would be much less than building new ones.

OTTAWA, Ontario.

I submit the following report on the schools in The Pas Agency, inspected during the Treaty Payment from June 1st until June 15th.

Big Eddy Day School:

Mr. Taylor teaches this school. He is a man well up in years but in my opinion is doing very excellent work. He is active and apparently in good health.

There were some cases of measles on this end of the reserve and this has cut down the attendance. I found ten pupils present. They appeared quite well along and I judge are making fair progress.

The school building is in good repair but needs interior decoration. The plaster is very dirty and the woodwork is dull and in need of paint.

The teacher's house is poorly constructed and small. After the war a new house should be provided.

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.
Ottawa, June 28, 1944.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Manitoba,

Reporting on his visit to the Big Eddy Day School, Inspector Hamilton states that the school requires interior decoration. He also states that the plaster is very dirty and the woodwork requires painting. Please let me know the approximate cost of doing this work and if it could be done during the summer.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

This work, for material and labour, would cost about $75.00 and I could get it done during August if you would give me the necessary authority.

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Manitoba.

R. A. Hoey,

The school has no system of ventilation and is very cold. Last winter I had to wear three pairs of socks in my mocassins, ski pants, a heavy woollen jacket and over this a man's outdoor parka in school. The frost comes in on the walls in the forty below weather.

Ottawa, June 6th, 1947.

c/o Inspector A.G. Hamilton,

Winnipeg, Manitoba.

Dear Major Clark:

We have received your telegrams and letters and have gleaned much useful information there from. Two problems have arisen which we would like you to handle before returning here.

One is at Edmonton and our telegrams to you have explained the situation sufficiently.

The second is at the Pas. If you will read the attached letter of last year from Mr. Dryden, the Minister of Education for Manitoba and our own Minister's reply thereto, you will get a good idea of the situation that exists at Big Eddy.

We have $5,000 now available for the construction of an extra room at the Big Eddy School. I want you to go and see Mr. Rogers, the Chief Inspector of Schools for the Province of Manitoba. We are quite prepared to put an addition onto our school and to have the Half-breed children attend. Then they can close down their present school.

I am going to try to inform Mr. Bateman, the local School Inspector, and Mr. Lovell, the local Indian Agent, of your estimated arrival so that they can go to Big Eddy with you. Apparently it is some eight miles from the Pas.

When there I want you to look the school over carefully and decide what will be needed in the way of an addition. Confidentially, we can tell you that we do not want to send anyone from our Surveys and Engineering
Branch in to look over the situation unless it is absolutely necessary. They are now swamped with work and if we could get a local contractor to submit a bid as to what we want, then I think we can get approval without much difficulty. Mr. Bateman and Mr. Lovell will probably know local conditions and may know of someone who can handle this situation. If we waste a lot of time with blue prints, etc., etc., we will end the summer with no school building but lots of red tape still to be cut. If necessary, make a sketch upon which a fairly skilled carpenter can go to work, but I will leave the details to your own good judgment.

Would you also discuss with Mr. Lovell the situation re a school at Nelson House. We have $8,000 in the estimates now for a combined school and teacher's residence at this point. I understand from him that it will be necessary to purchase the materials this year and ship them in for construction next year.

Please get as much information as you can concerning the shipping in of materials so that you will be able to advise us when they are being sent in next winter.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

P.S. The Minister's letters are both confidential and you should not let them get out of your possession.

Dear Sir:

Regarding the construction of the new class-room at Big Eddy. When Major Clark was here from the Department, he secured a tender on this building, which ran over the estimate. I assured Major Clark that I could handle this building with a foreman and Indian labour. Soon after Mr. Clark left I was confined to hospital and then to the house, the consequence was that I could not give this work the attention I expected to. But I secured a bid for labour to erect this school for the sum of $1800.00 with the understanding that as much as possible of the labour would be Indian.

As regards the amount appropriated for this school I would appreciate it very much if the amount of $500.00 could be added as I intend to dig a well in the basement, also I will have to buy stove, sink, etc to complete the kitchen. I can assure you that it will not be a dollar spent that is not absolutely necessary.

This school is situated on the main highway which will evidently run from The Pas to Flin Flon, and I would not want to have to skimp any work for a few dollars.

Mr. Philan,

Progress on enlarged Big Eddy School

Because of Mr. Indian Agent Lovell's absence your request for details had to be left unanswered.

I have gone over the building with the foreman, Mr. Paul Popovich, and am greatly surprised at the transformation that has been worked.

There will be two classrooms, each 30' long, one 21' wide, the other 24' wide, and 10' high.

Each will have five windows 5' x 3'. I am emphasizing that these should be adapted for opening at the top; proper storm windows to be fitted; fly screens to be provided.

The basement (18' x 12') cost a lot more than estimated as it had to be fully concreted on all sides to a height of 7' to prevent the gravel on which the old school was built from continually slipping.

Mr. Popovich claims to have built successfully many of the type of inside wells which we want.

The old lath and plaster had to be thrown out, and they are "waiting" for Gyproc wall finishing.

Painting has not yet been begun. Mr. Lovell has secured good paint in attractive colours.

The working gang of six Indians will, Mr. Popovich says, be reduced by half next week.

The bricklayers will then go to work on a new chimney. Meanwhile, could you advise regarding our purchasing agent's prospects of getting that over-size camp heater, please?

I recommend sympathetic consideration of the Agent's request for an additional $500.

C.C.J. Clarke

Mrs. Lovell,

Big Eddy School - Windows

In the new room the contractor has not allowed anything like the proper ratio of window area to floor area.

Dimensions of room: 30' x 24' Area 720 sq ft.
Manitoba standard is 20% window i.e. 144 sq ft.
Room has five windows 4' x 2½' area of 50 sq ft.
i.e. there is only about ⅓ of the desirable amount.

Before the walls are finished more windows will have to be added. I have discussed this matter with the foreman, Mr. Popovich, and the following additions are possible and necessary. Please instruct all concerned.

(a) One more window 4' x 2½' to be added to the row of five; the added window to be at the end of the row nearer the front of the room.

(b) Two windows approximately 3' x 2' each to be let into the top of the wall along the back of the room. These to be equipped with attachments to permit being easily opened.

(c) Three of the large windows, preferably all of them, to be made to open easily from the top.

These changes will give a window-floor ratio of 1:10 and allow something nearer the ventilation standard.

Memo for Dr. D. Cameron.

Don:

Our Dr. Yule at The Pas was telling me with respect to the school which is called Big Eddy School, about a dozen miles out of The Pas, that the heating arrangements are very bad. There is a stove which is really inadequate. He knows this isn't exactly his business but he is concerned about it from the viewpoint of the health of the students, about 50% of whom, (being Indians), are charges of his. He believes that the health of the student is going to suffer by reason of the inadequacy. I understand this is one of those schools run by the province and Dominion jointly because of a mixture of half breeds and Indians and that in this case there is a majority of Indians and consequently, the job is a Dominion one rather than a Provincial one. I guess the matter referred to is one for Bob Howey. There isn't any Indian Agent at The Pas just now; the last man having died a few months ago.

R.M.

Lyn - Can you find out the facts for me please so that I can reply to Maybank.

G.D.W.Cameron

No complaints so far

C.A.F.C.
Mr. G.D.W. Cameron,
Deputy Minister of Health,
Jackson Building.

EX'D.
Nov. 27/47

Mr. Maybank's letter to you of Nov. 18 - Big Eddy School

I have discussed this situation with
Major C.A.F. Clark, Field Superintendent of Schools
for Indian Affairs, Dept. of Mines and Resources.

He advises me that this school is the
responsibility of the department although a certain
proportion of the children are provincial responsibility.
However, as the majority of the children attending the
school are Seminon, they have assumed responsibility
for its administration.

Last year it was operated as a one-room
school, but it is expected that commencing January 1st,
a second room will be open. The construction work was
done during the past summer.

Major Clark advises me that last year the
teacher complained of the school; particularly her
residence, being very cold and during this summer the
building was insulated and a new heater purchased for
the school. He has had no complaints this fall but
states he is writing to make further enquiries.

If we obtain any further information, you
will be immediately advised.

W.L. Falconer,
Asst. Director, Indian Health Services.

Dear Sir:

Please refer to your letter of 22nd inst., file 128-15-5 (WT) regarding Big Eddy Indian Day School. The water level has lowered considerably in the inside well at the school. I believe that this well will prove satisfactory if we are granted permission to increase the depth of the well by using an auger. The well would have to be pumped dry first.

Regarding the complaint you received regarding heating of school, presumably from Dr. Yule, at the time he was out there, the storm windows had not been put on. I have visited the school many times since, and found it comfortable. I would suggest that coal be used in addition to wood in order to keep a more steady heat in the building during the night. Our estimates only asked for two tons of coal. This will be inadequate. Five tons would be a more feasible estimate, due to the building being doubled in size. Some kind of grate would have to be installed in the camp comfort furnace. However, I will purchase two thermometers and we can draw our conclusions from them at a later date.

EDUCATION DIVISION

Dear Sir:

Regarding Mr. Moffat's inspection of Big Eddy School in your letter of the 22nd inst., file 126-15-5 (E1), I would advise that some repairs are necessary but I was withholding submitting my request for additional expenditure until the starting of the fiscal year 1948-49.

A large camp comfort stove was installed instead of a furnace to keep down expenses as we only had $5,000.00 to work on in building and remodelling this combined school, and we overexpended this sum as it was. At that time Mr. Lovell felt this camp comfort would give sufficient heat for this building. I still think it can give sufficient heat if fired at night and early morning, but the fire is left when school is dismissed and not finished until school opening, thus the building gets quite cold during the night. During school period a good heat comes from both hot air registers. However, if a furnace was installed, it would cut down on the fuel bill considerably as coal could be used to hold a fire all night, and less wood would be burned.

The doors on the school are fitted properly, but due to frost they stick. As there are no storm doors on the school, no protection from the outside weather is supplied. Weather-stripping would also prevent the cold seeping in.

I instructed the plumber to put save troughs over the doors while he was at Big Eddy School, but he forgot and I didn't press him, as we were overexpended. The roof should have save troughing all around to prevent ice from accumulating at doors and windows. There is about 175 feet of save troughing and a spout at each corner.

The cupboard Miss Montgomery had in the old school fell to pieces when being removed during rebuilding of the combined school. It is requested that a similar cupboard to the one in Miss Irwin's room be built for Miss Montgomery. The cost of it was $75.00.

Trusting this is the information you require,

Your obedient servant,

T.A. Bowman,

School Inspector's Report -
Big Eddy Indian Day School.

Mr. Moffat's report of October 19th on the above school has now been received here. His comments on Mrs. Montgomery's teaching ability are only fair. We have previously discussed this matter and you are aware that it is our intention to transfer her to a smaller school when the occasion arises. However, I note that she is teaching only some twenty children at the present time. He grades her as C plus for teaching skill, management, initiative and discipline. In General Comment he states as follows:

"Although, Miss Montgomery is not a particularly energetic type of teacher, I would rate her work as fair. I do believe her to be capable of better work, however, if her interest were greater".

His comments concerning Mrs. Gratton is much more satisfactory. However, I note that apparently these children are still being separated as to being Indians and Half-Breeds. Your comment on this would be appreciated. In recommending that Mrs. Gratton be retained for another year, Mr. Moffat states as follows:

"Mrs. Gratton is a very capable teacher who is handling her class very well indeed. Her discipline is excellent without being at all oppressive".
Buildings and Equipment.

Under this heading Mr. Moffat writes as follows:

"Toilet paper and disinfectant should be secured. The school well has gone dry. A spring is being used as a source of water supply. Steps should be taken to ensure an adequate supply of water at the school. The heating unit is a camp comfort stove enclosed with a zinc jacket which works well enough in all but the colder weather. In colder weather it is impossible to keep the school warm according to Mrs. Montgomery. A cupboard is needed in Mrs. Montgomery's room. There should also be a library bookcase provided for each room. The school is without a fire extinguisher. A storm door on the North door would help to solve the heating problem.

A second toilet should be built. At present there is but one toilet for the whole school".

You are hereby authorized to make local purchase of the following:

36 rolls Toilet Paper
12 tins Chloride of Lime
3 large bottles Lysol

You are also authorized to build a second toilet at a cost not to exceed $100. It is presumed that we will have your comments concerning the water situation. You may also build a storm door. If we could have an approximate cost of the last item, the necessary authority can be provided.

We are ordering the cupboards, bookcases and fire extinguishers required through the Departmental Purchasing Agent. The bookcases will be unpainted and you can arrange to have them varnished or painted when they arrive.

You might take an opportunity of advising Mr. Moffat of the action taken on his report.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education."

Mr. H. Law,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
The Pas, Manitoba.

Big Eddy Indian Day School,

I have for answer your letters of November 4 and November 10 with regard to the teachers at the above Indian Day School. We regret sincerely the apparent non-receipt of your letter of October 12 and are now having an investigation made as to why this letter was not brought to our attention at an earlier date.

Mrs. Gatten's cheques will be forwarded in the near future and would you please express to her our regrets at this long delay and assure her that we will do everything possible to ensure that her cheques arrive regularly in future.

We have also noted your comments with regard to Miss Montgomery and hope that Major Clark will have an opportunity of inspecting her work in the near future.

We are pleased to note that the toilet paper, etc., has been provided and an accountable cheque for $34.00 for the well will be forwarded at once.

The Department approves the granting of a leave of absence of one week's duration, for Miss Montgomery. It would be appreciated if we could be advised when she returns to duty at this school.

Bernard F. Henry,
Superintendent of Education.

February 3, 1949.

Mr. Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education
Indian Affairs Branch

Dear Sir,

I wish to bring to your attention that the Big Eddy School is not warm enough. When the temperature outdoors falls below ten degrees beyond zero, the temperature of the old part of the school does not rise above forty degrees. The heating facilities are inadequate. Mr. Davis was to see about purchasing a new heating system in Ottawa. If then the school is this cold it is extremely difficult to keep discipline. Mrs. Dyratton has noticed this too. She is a capable teacher and has splendid discipline in her class. The first two years I taught in Big Eddy in the old building.
the temperature was even colder than in the new school. When I had several big unruly boys in a small overcrowded classroom. These boys are now beyond school age.

Is it possible to secure metal scissors? The plastic ones are useless. Indian children have the tendency to be destructive; easily broken articles further their mischief.

I have one more Grade XII subject to write off to entitle me to my First Class Standing Teacher's Certificate in Manitoba. To obtain this, one needs a certain number of years teaching experience (Grade XII English, 7½ units at summer school and some other subject). Would this standing qualify me for further advancement in your Department?

The teacherage is warmer since the repairs were made and coal is provided.

Yours sincerely,

E. B. Montgomery

Mr. Chelan:
The "heating plant" at Big Eddy, as you know, was completed locally because furnaces were unavailable at that time. It could be transferred to a one-room school if a proper furnace was supplied to Big Eddy.

CATC.
10th February, 1949.

Mr. E. Law,
Superintendent, Indian Agency,
The Pas, Manitoba.

Following is an extract from a letter which we have just received from Miss E.B. Montgomery, teacher at the Big Eddy Day School:

"I wish to bring to your attention that the Big Eddy Day School is not warm enough. When the temperature outside falls 10 degrees below zero, the temperature of the old part of the school does not rise above 40 degrees. The heating facilities are inadequate. The teachersage is warmer since the repairs were made and coal is provided."

We understand that the main trouble with the heating system at this school is that the furnace in it was assembled locally due to the fact that we could not secure a proper furnace at the time. However, we thought that possibly you might make some repairs to the present heating system so that it will carry us through the balance of this winter. You could then bring the matter to our attention early in April, when arrangements can be made to secure a new furnace during the summer months.

You should inform Mrs. Montgomery that the contents of her letter have been brought to your attention, and you might advise us later what action you have taken in the matter.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLICUES CANADA
Ottawa, March 30, 1914.

With Cheque,

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd instant enclosing a return of attendance at the Black River Day School for the period which the school was in operation during the current quarter and also an order from the teacher in your favour for $21.60.

In reply I beg to inform you that the salary is paid for 26 days, this being the number the school was open from the beginning of the quarter to February 6th last. A cheque drawn in favour of Mr. Jeremiah Henderson, the late teacher, for $39.00, being the amount of salary due, is enclosed herewith. The Department cannot, under a ruling of the Treasury Board, recognize any order in favour of an official in the employ of the government. If you will have Mr. Henderson endorse this cheque you should then be in a position to adjust with him the amount of his indebtedness to you.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, January 20, 1921.

Sir,

In checking over the returns for the Black River Indian Day School it is noted that during the year 1920 the school was open as follows: March quarter 48 days; June quarter 45 days; September quarter 18 days and December quarter 43 days, or, a total of 157 days throughout the whole year.

As the Department requires that all Indian day schools should be open 200 days in the year, you will notice that the teacher at this point is apparently not giving as satisfactory service as he should.

You will be good enough to bring this matter to his attention and it is hoped that during the present year the number of days the school is open will conform with the Department's requirements.

Your obedient servant

J. D. McLean,

Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant in regard to the Black River School Building, Berens River Agency, and to say that on the 12th of January last John Sayer, Chief of that Band, reported that "the house that is being used for a school now is very old and is now rotten, the only thing that is keeping it up is the mud with which it is plastered. When the rain comes in the spring and the mud falls the building will fall too." On the 1st of March Mr. Agent Shute wrote: "I think it is necessary to complete the building; as to the cost of doing so I can say nothing, as I am 150 miles from there. Rev. Henry Thomas will be able to give you the information." Under the circumstances I thought it would be wise to take the means of completing said building and obtained the estimate which was forwarded to the Department on the 19th ultimo.

I now beg to recommend that the sum of $300.00 be authorized to be expended for the said purpose.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Commissioner.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector McCall in his Annual Report under the heading of "Education" calls attention to the fact that the old school-house of the Black River Band, in the Severn River Agency, is in a dilapidated condition and is positively unfit for the purpose for which it is intended, neither affording protection against either the rain in summer or the cold in winter. He says that a well constructed foundation of neatly fitted logs with dovetailed corners has been standing for some time awaiting completion, and that the Indians are anxious to have the building finished since they have done their part of the work.

Although no funds are specially voted for this purpose in the current year's Estimates, you may, if you think it advisable, authorize the work to be proceeded with. The amount previously estimated was $250.00, which lapsed, and it is thought that this amount should be sufficient to complete the work.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

The charge for tobacco was as in the other cases of Jack Head and Blood Vein River given in payment of Indian Labor. It must also be remembered that on Lake Winnipeg there are no roads and any movement represents expense in hiring boats and men to return said boats hence charges of this kind. It is difficult to take receipts always for small amounts.

Freighting Accounts are duly receipted. Robinson and the N.W.M. Co and the Dominion Fish Company are one and the same.

At Black River reserve the work is in the hands of Mr George Slater; he does good work with the Indians; the work is elementary; the school building is old but is in good condition; the equipment is ample and in good order. The roof of the house occupied as living quarters by Mr Slater leaks pretty badly, it is mission property I think.

Bishop Lofthouse intimated the following: if the Department would furnish the shingles and nails to fasten same that Mr Slater would do the work of shingling.

Jno. P. Bunn
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

OTTAWA, May 27th, 1921.

Sir,

Mr. Geo. Slater, teacher of the Black River Indian Day School, in his annual report for the last fiscal year, states that the school is very much in need of a box stove, as the one in use is in very poor condition, being cracked on the side.

I have, therefore, to request that you will be good enough to arrange for the purchase and delivery of a suitable stove, and the necessary stove pipes, for the use of this school. Before making these purchases, you should obtain competitive prices.

As this stove, no doubt, will not be required until next Fall, you should arrange to have same delivered at a later date—in time to be set up before the cold weather sets in.

After the purchase has been made, you should furnish properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a memorandum showing the firms asked to quote, and the prices quoted by each, and if it is necessary to pay any freight charges, receipts for the same should also be attached to the vouchers.

You should not overlook the purchase of this stove during the coming summer, and complete arrangements to have it sent to the school in due time.

Your obedient servant,

Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

BLACK RIVER DAY SCHOOL.

This school is situated on the north bank of Black River. It is a log structure, 17 x 22, sided on the outside. The building has never been painted and is certainly in need of it.

At present 13 are on the roll, 9 treaty and 4 non-treaty. The attendance here is only fair and the work only reaches grade III.

The pupils are rather backward and I am of the opinion that very little is accomplished at this school.

Mr. Geo. Slater is in charge here. He is not qualified and there is no style about his teaching. I realize this is an isolated reserve and no doubt it would be difficult to obtain a qualified teacher and yet I feel no headway is being made at the present time.

The blackboard is only 8 ft. long and worn out. A new board, 16 ft., should be supplied. The floor is also badly worn. If a new floor with paper between were laid it would greatly add to the comfort of the place during the winter.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Hamilton, in a report on his recent visit to the Black River Indian Day School, states that the school building has never been painted and is badly in need of same. He also states that a blackboard is required and that the floor is badly worn. He further states that if a new floor with paper between were laid it would add to the comfort of the building.

It is, no doubt, too late in the season to undertake any of the work mentioned, and I have to request that you will draw this matter to the attention of the Department early next spring. You should at that time furnish an estimate of the cost of painting this building, also the cost of any new flooring required. When this information is received, consideration will then be given to authorizing the work. At the same time you should inform the Department as to the length and width of any new blackboard required, and whether chalk trough and moulding are also required. Directions for shipping the blackboard should be given.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,

CANADA
Ottawa, August 12th, 1925.

Very Rev. Sir,

I have been directed to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, relative to teachers for the next school year for the Berens River R.C. and Bloodvein R.C. Indian Day Schools.

In reply I beg to say that the Department will approve of the transfer of Miss Patricia Fuller, who is now teacher at the Berens River School, to take charge of the Bloodvein School.

We will also approve of the appointment of Rev. Brother Leach as teacher of the Berens River School to succeed Miss Fuller. The salary allowed Rev. Father Leach will be at the rate of $60 per month for 10 teaching months in the year. It is understood that, besides the teaching of the school, he will be responsible for the dispensing of medicines to the Indians at Berens River.

We will allow Miss Fuller salary at the same rate as she was paid at Berens River, viz., $60 per month for the 10 teaching months in the year, and she should also attend to any dispensing of medicines that will be required.

We are informing Mr. Agent Latulippe and Mr. Commissioner Graham of the approval granted for the above appointments for the next school year.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Very Rev. J. B. Boye, O.M.I.,
340 Provencher Ave.,
St. Boniface, Man.

CANADA
Ottawa, October 15, 1925.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 5th instant enclosing copy of a communication which you received from Miss Fuller, teacher of the Bloodvein R.C. Indian Day School requesting that a change be made in the period at which the holidays are allowed.

In reply I beg to say that in view of the teacher's explanation that most of the pupils are away during the winter, the Department will approve of this school being closed for six weeks during the coming winter and two weeks next summer. This arrangement is only approved for one year and its further continuance will depend upon the success which the change in the holidays meets.

You should notify the Department in due time of the dates between which the school will be closed next winter. You may inform Miss Fuller of the authority granted for the change in the holiday period at this school.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

(A. F. MacKenzie)
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

H. O. Latulippe, Esq.,

J. D. McLean Esq.,

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

I have received a cheque no 3394 dated Oct. 15th 25 to the value of eighty dollars $80.00 stated to be my salary.

Would you kindly inform me in what proportion this cheque should be divided.

As under instructions, my dispensing and teaching duties commenced on Aug. 17th. I can not quite balance the above cheque.

I remain,

Your faithful servant,

Patricia J. Weber.
Ottawa, November 10, 1925.

Madam:

In reply to your letter of the 29th ultimo regarding cheque No.3394 for $80.00 sent you on the 15th ultimo, I beg to say that this was in payment of your salary as teacher at the Bloodvein River Day School for the month of September. The Department is not aware of any instructions having been given to you to commence teaching duties at this school on August 17th. Bloodvein River school was closed for holidays on June 30th last, and we understood that the usual two months holiday would be taken. Please communicate with Mr. Agent Latulippe regarding this matter and also your request for payment for your services as dispenser of medicines. If he considers it necessary he will communicate with the Department. In matters of this kind, in future, you should communicate with the Indian Agent and not direct to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Miss Patricia Fuller,
Teacher,
Bloodvein River R.C.
Day School,

Sir:

I beg to thank you for the remittance of $240.00 by wire to my credit at the Bank of Montreal Winnipeg.

This covers my salary for the quarter ending 31st December 1925, as teacher in the Indian Day School (R.C.) on the Bloodvein Indian Reserve, in Glandaboye Agency.

My residence as teacher at the above named school is located out of bounds for any local Post Office, the nearest Post Office being 15 miles away.

At the suggestion of Mr. Inspector Bunn I have opened a Savings Account in the Main Office of the Bank of Montreal in Winnipeg, the number of my Pass Book is Account "D" No. 7884, and for future salary cheques I would be obliged if you would kindly send these to the Bank of Montreal and the bank has promised to advise when these are received and placed to my credit.

The above arrangement will provide against a recurrence of the difficulty I have just experienced, and which was relieved by the attention of Mr. Bunn.

Your obedient servant,

Patricia Fuller.

Teacher Indian Day School (R.C.)
on Bloodvein Indian Reserve,
Glandaboye Agency, Man.,
Lake Winnipeg

Sir,

The Department authorized the establishment of a day school on the Bloodvein Indian Reserve under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church. A request has now been received for the supplying of fifteen double desks for this school, and I have to request that you will be good enough to obtain prices from a number of dealers for the following desks, namely:

- 5 Double Separate Desks for children from 7 to 9 years of age
- 5 " " " " 9 " 12 " "
- 5 " " " " 12 " 16 " "

also three fronts only for the smaller size and three rears for the larger size desks. You may purchase the fifteen desks and the three fronts and three rears from the dealers quoting the lowest price and have them shipped to the Rev. F. Leach, C.M.I., c/o Northern Fish Co., Little Bull Head, Via Selkirk, Man.

In order to save freight charges, these desks should be shipped in a knock down condition and they can be assembled and set up at the school.

You should inform the Rev. Father Leach of the date of shipment from Selkirk, in order that he can arrange to have them placed in position in the school-room.

You should furnish properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the desks, together with the prices received by you from the various dealers.

A request has also been received for the supplying of a stove for this school together with six lengths of stove pipes and two elbows. You should also obtain prices from a number of dealers for a suitable stove, stove pipes and elbows and purchase from the one quoting the lowest price. The Department will leave the kind and size of the stove to your judgement, and you should also arrange to have these forwarded to Rev. Father Leach. You should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred in the purchase of the stove, stove pipes and elbows, together with the quotations received by you attached.

I shall be pleased if you will give the matter of the purchasing of the desks and stove your early attention and have them forwarded as soon as possible. Rev. Father Leach is being informed that the purchase of the above material is being placed in your hands.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Sir:

Sir:

Selkirk, Man. June 4th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter No. 202-11A Gen. of the last instant relative to new school proposed for the Bloodvein Reserve.

I consider that this work should be done by contract and in view of no logs being available since the fires last summer, I do not consider the sum of $1500.00 out of the way for a frame school.

Consideration would have to be allowed for freighting this material both on the S.S. Kenora and again from Matheson Island by gas boat to the Reserve.

As there are no carpenters among the Bloodvein Indians, I would suggest that as many as possible be engaged by the contractor for to do the rough work.

Regarding the Contractor, Mr. J. M. Turner, member for Springfield constituency has written a letter asking that Mr. Hugh McKay of Garacon, Manitoba be given consideration by being allowed to tender.

Yours very truly,

EM/FL
Dear Sir,

I received a visit from the Rev. Father Provincial and Brother Leach re the new school to be erected on the Bloodvein reserve.

The fire has destroyed all the good timber and logs will not be available. The school will need to be of frame construction and the Indians are not carpenters. Brother Leach figured he could have the building erected for $1500.00 and would like to undertake the work. He is convinced it will cost more if given to a contractor. I am sure Brother Leach would satisfy the Department if he were allowed to erect the building.

Mr. McPherson, the Agent, states as per the attached letter that the building should be by contract but beyond that has made no recommendation. I believe the material will cost, F.O.B. Bloodvein, at least $1,000.00 or $1200.00 and labor will run from $400.00 to $500.00.

I would like this work started not later than July 10th and would appreciate knowing if the work is to be by contract or day labor, and what parties are to be consulted in connection with the work.

Yours truly,

A.G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Manitoba.

Included in the Special Supplementary Estimates was an item of $1,500 for the erection of a new day school on the Bloodvein Indian Reserve. This reserve is situated in a very isolated place, approximately 120 miles north of Winnipeg.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton, Inspector of Indian Agencies, Winnipeg, Manitoba, recommends that Brother Leach, who is at present at the Bloodvein R. C. Indian Mission be employed as foreman and Indian labour used. The materials would be purchased in Winnipeg by Mr. Hamilton and forwarded by boat.

Brother Leach is a very competent builder and has been employed for many years at different Indian schools in the West which are conducted under Roman Catholic auspices.

Mr. Hamilton considers that, by purchasing the materials in Winnipeg and engaging Brother Leach as foreman, a school suitable for the Bloodvein Reserve could be erected for the amount available, namely, $1,500.00. It is understood, of course, that the accounts for the material would be submitted here for payment and, also, paylists for the labour.

I strongly recommend Mr. Hamilton's suggestion. If you concur, I would appreciate immediate arrangements being made to proceed with this work. Mr. Hamilton advises that the work should be started not later than July 16th.

Selkirk, Man., April 22, 1942.

Dear Sir:

You will note that Brother Leach has requested on the attached requisition for school supplies for the Bloodvein Indian Day School that the Department supply him with some stain for the school floor and stain for the roof.

J. W. Morrison & Company, Selkirk, quote as follows on these items:

- 2 Gallons Mahogany Floor Stain No. 1 Grade @ $5.60 - $11.20
- 8 Gallons Red Shingle Stain @ $1.75 per gallon - $14.00
- 1 Shingle Stain Brush 4 Inch. - $1.75

$26.95

Brother Leach advises that the school was last painted in 1937 when both the floor and the roof received one coat of stain. He states that both are now badly in need of re-painting and if funds are available, I would recommend that the required material be purchased. There will be no expense to the Department in connection with labour to put the paint on.

Very truly yours,

E. McPherson,
Indian Agent.

In Sept. last, the Rev. L. Leclair recommended me for the appointment as teacher of the Brokenhead Indian Day School. In your reply to him dated the 5th Nov. 175821, you stated, that the Dept could not consent to my appointment as I had proved a failure at Hollow Water River. Now, Sir, I would like to know in what way I proved a failure, and who put in the report to that effect? I was at Hollow Water River 14 years & 3 months and not only taught the school but was the catechist in charge. I tried to do my duty in every way. I often had to cut my own wood at the school, and often hauled wood to the school for the Indians for nothing in order to keep the school going. I did my best to keep up the attendance, but this is very hard to do when the Indians move around so much in the summer. They have to do so, as it would be impossible for them to make a living on the reserve all the year round. Now Sir, if any man can do more than this, I should think he would have to be more than mere mortal. Hence, I would say in justice to myself who have been in the service of the Department so long, they should give me a chance to defend myself and not throw me over in my old age.

On my recent visit to the Brokenhead Indian Reserve, I had two applications for the position of teacher in the day school, one from John Sinclair, whose application I have been informed the department have dealt with. The other applicant was Miss. Bella Monkman, a young girl of 17 years of age. Her people live on a farm adjoining the reserve and one mile from the school. She has only had a public school education and attended school at Aliston, which adjoins the town of Selkirk, and is generally a pretty well conducted school. She writes a neat hand and understands the elements of arithmetic and from what I can judge well enough informed for the position as teacher.

This school has been without a teacher since the December quarter, and it appears to be impossible to get a teacher, as there is no place where they can board.

I know nothing of Mr. Sinclair personally, but he has been a long while working for the department, and I presume they will know what value to place upon his services.

In one case the applicant is 72 years of age, with many years of experience, the other is 17 years of age and no experience, but seems to be willing to attempt the work and promises to do the best that she can.

I might say that at a meeting of the council I was pressed to hire the appointment of Mr. Sinclair.

Most Reverend Sir:

I learned that the teacher's health was not good and I found many children in the village in necessity, who should have been at school. At that time I took no action on the complaint, because dissension in an Indian band often leads to statements that are far from accurate on the part of one group or another.

Dear Sir, re Brokenhead Indian School, Scantebury, Manitoba

Your Department operates a school known as the Brokenhead Indian School on the reserve near Scantebury, and this Department is concerned in a public school district known as the School District of Stony Point. Our Inspector, Mr. Andrew Willows, is of the opinion that these two schools could be amalgamated with advantage to both communities and he thinks the proper site for a school to serve all parties concerned is on the Reserve near the present Post Office.

We understand that your Department is considering the erection of a new building as the present school building on the Reserve is unsatisfactory, and I am writing to suggest that such new building be so placed, if possible, that your Department and this Department might share equally in the operating expenses of the school and that it might serve both communities. The public school district has not yet erected its own building but has been carrying on in a private house. The two schools combined would furnish a sufficient number of children to make a first class school possible and the expense would be reduced considerably if we could co-operate along the lines suggested herein.

I shall be glad if you will enquire into this matter and let me have your opinion on it. Thanking you,

MEMO FOR FILE:

I discussed the proposed amalgamation of the Brokenhead Indian Day School and the Stony Point white School with Dr. Fletcher, Public School Inspector Willows and the Venerable Archdeacon Thomas, now Bishop of Brandon. There are 25 children enrolled at present in the Indian school, but some are not Indian. The Stony Point school district have no school building, but a site on the reserve near Monkman's, one mile west of the station of Scantebury, would be suitable for the white children. I believe it would also be central for the Indians that attend.

It appears that this Department would have to bear all the capital expense but that the current expenses would be divided. Mr. Inspector Willows would supervise the activity of the school and would be responsible for the appointment of a teacher.

I believe that the Department would be well advised to erect a building in the near future, as soon as funds can be provided, and correspond with the Department of Education in Winnipeg relative to the current expense and management of the school.

Sir:-

Stevenson, Indian Agent at Selkirk, pointing out that since the erection of the new school at Brokenhead the roll of pupils has increased from twenty to thirty. Dear Mr. MacKenzie,

You will recall that when a year ago the Rev. F. Longmore was appointed teacher of the school at Scantebury your Department made the condition that it should be only for one year. For two reasons I am writing to request that his tenure of office may be extended for another year. In the first place, as far as I have learned from the Inspector and from the parents of the children, he has done satisfactory work and is, what is important, quite popular with the Indians of the Reserve. In the second place, I am finding it increasingly more difficult to light upon suitable teachers for these Indian Day Schools and if Mr. Longmore gives up I shall be at my wits' end to find a successor for him. The man is a well educated man and has had considerable experience as a teacher. I shall be greatly relieved, therefore, if the Department will consent to have him remain for another year. I may add that I did not expect to have to make this request, as I had other intentions in regard to Mr. Longmore for next year, but on account of my probable absence at the Lambeth Conference in London until September I do not see how I can secure the time to look out for someone else. Ottawa, September 11, 1928.

Sir:

I have to inform you that His Grace the Archbishop of Rupert's Land has nominated Rev. John A. Maggrah as teacher of the Brokenhead Indian Day School. The Department is approving of his appointment, and it is hoped that you will give him every assistance you can. Salary will be allowed at the rate of $55 per teaching month.

Mr. Maggrah's appointment will be as teacher of the Indian children only, as it has been decided not to take any action towards having a combined white and Indian day school.

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, October 5, 1928.

Most Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, relative to the appointment of Rev. J. A. Maggrah as teacher of the Brokenhead Indian Day School and the amount of salary he is to receive. In reply I have to inform Your Grace that the Department will allow Mr. Maggrah salary at the same rate as was paid his predecessor, Mr. Conlin, viz.: $55 per teaching month for his services as teacher. Besides, he will be allowed the sum of $50 per annum for his services as dispenser. The local Indian agent and Mr. Commissioner Graham are being informed.

I have the honour to be,

Most Reverend Sir,

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLEAN

REPORT FOR THE MONTH OF MAY 1936

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, June 5, 1936.

Dear Sir:

Referring to that portion of your report for the month of May, last, in which you drew attention to the need of a well at the Brokenhead Indian Day School, I would request that you furnish full information. Would it be necessary to drill the well or would a dug well meet the requirements? Further, if the latter would be satisfactory, please state if the Indians could carry out the labour. If possible, you should give an estimate of the depth required to dig a well in order to obtain a good supply of water. You should state, also, the cost of installing a pump. When this information is received, consideration will be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided during the present fiscal year.

Yours truly,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Gentlemen:

I beg to report having accompanied the treaty party making annual treaty payments to reserves on Lake Winnipeg belonging to the Clandeboye Agency.

The health of the Indians is improving due to their better living conditions and better furs, better prices, and more employment for those going out and seeking same. This is reflected in the decreasing number of T.B. cases that I see and children getting more nourishment their resistance is improving.

The mid day meal at XXX schools has been a great help in building up the children. Also I have advised that the children coming to school be given Cod Liver Oil following the meal. When this is given by the Teacher we know they are getting something that is a big help to their physical condition. We know that if given the Cod Liver Oil to take home, it very often is not used. I saw only one case of Scrofula, amongst all the children. I saw on the trip. It was at Berens River.

At Bloodbein Reserve I saw three cases of T.B. but they were too weak to bring out for treatment. This Reserve seems to have more T.B. than others. Their health is well looked after by Brother Leach the Teacher here but their resistance is poor.

W.H.G. Gibbs

Memo:

ATTENTION: Mr. Phelan

Re: Brokenhead Indian Day School

Photo No. 1 shows the congested condition of the single classroom. It is desired to increase the floor area to provide more room both for the increasing number of Indian children and to accommodate a number of non-Indian children for whom the Province does not provide a convenient school.

Photo No. 2 shows the existing school and the ration house behind it. The school is oriented with windows facing the north. The number of windows is, in any case, too few.

Photo No. 3 shows the school and the fine new teacherage. This Photo confirms the opinion expressed by the teacher and the agent that the school is too close to the road, and that the windows face the wrong way. Traffic noise disturbs the proceedings in school.

Photo No. 4 shows the area at the left to which Mr. Supt. Olson desires to move the school. His plan as outlined to me orally, would involve:

(a) moving the school onto new footings,
(b) removing the partitions for the cloakrooms at the front of the school to add more desk space,
(c) adding windows facing toward the south,
(d) conversion of the existing addition to other purposes (e.g. cloakroom, lunch room).

I would recommend that as the plan seems a reasonable and economical project, the Superintendent be requested to forward diagrams and details of his suggestions to this office.

C.A.F. Clark

This is in reply to Mr. Neary's letter - file 505-5 (E.1) -
regarding modernization and moving of the Brokenhead Indian Day School. I write this through your office for your information and recommendation.

Mr. Neary's letter requested estimate for the following:

(a) Moving the school onto new footings
(b) Removing the partitions for the cloakrooms at the front of the school to add more desk space.
(c) Adding windows and facing of windows toward the south.
(d) Conversion of the existing addition to other purposes (e.g., cloakroom, lunch room).

I took Mr. Neal McRea with me to check requirements and estimate costs and submit estimate as follows:

| Item                  | Cost   |
|-----------------------|--------|
| Digging basement      | $225.00|
| Gravel 70 yds.        | 210.00 |
| Building crib         | 125.00 |
| Running cement        | 175.00 |
| Taking down crib      | 50.00  |
| Levelling mud         | 60.00  |
| Moving building       | 500.00 |
| Flag pole             | 25.00  |

| Insulation            | 60.00  |
| Flooring              | 75.00  |
| Windows               | 40.00  |
| Chimney               | 150.00 |
| Furnace               | 250.00 |
| Cement                | 190.00 |
| 3 ply                 | 100.00 |

Total: $2585.00
In addition it is likely a beam under the building will be required at a cost of $25.00, floor joists at $35.00, lumber for building crib $270.00 and a paint job, inside and out, after work is completed at cost of $300.00.

The foregoing brings estimate cost to $3,215.00

I would particularly draw to your attention that basement and furnace is included in above estimate. The school being small no proper arrangement of space is feasible without this improvement. The heating unit should be removed from classroom and if any small basement hole is dug, such as one quarter size to accommodate furnace, for relatively small additional cost full basement, giving manual training and noon-meal facilities is most desirable.

I recommend this for your favorable consideration.

We have had considerable difficulty getting men to check over this work in order to secure competitive prices. Mr. McRea will re-model the school for $1,185.00.

It was our intention to put a basement in this school and move it to a different site. However, this would be so costly, I do not feel the move would warrant the expense; therefore, I have requested Mr. Olson to get a price on re-modelling the school - which includes taking out the present cloakroom and chimney, and putting it all into a classroom; relining and partitioning off the present warehouse, that is on the north side of the school, and making this the entrance and cloakrooms.

I consider Mr. McRea's price fairly reasonable, and Mr. Olson will give him authority, if possible, to get this work done - in order that the school will be ready to open in September.

Dear Sir,

I would like to inform you that on account of our mission work on Bloodvein Reserve, I had to buy a house which is used both as a residence for the visiting priest and a chapel for the Catholic Indians. I feel that you are entitled to be informed of this and I take the occasion to further advise you that the Indians are anxious to have a real little church of their own and an effort has already been made to make foundation for same and we will proceed to build the church next spring if nothing comes in the way in the meantime.

I am just back from my trip to Lake Winnipeg and I am surprised to not find on my desk your letter containing the list of Catholic children of school age at Berens River Reserve as promised at Mr Disbrow's office at Berens River.

Please send it to me as soon as possible as I am waiting here for it before I am able to forward to the Indian Department my petition for a Catholic School at Berens River and return to Berens River.

yours truly,

(Signed) S. Ferrault O.M.I.
However, this is only my opinion and I will submit your petition to the Department for its consideration and decision.

I have the honour to be

August 25th, 1917.

I have your two letters having reference to school and mission work in the Bloodvein Reserve and also making mention of my apparent negligence in the matter of forwarding you my list of Roman Catholic children of school age in the Berens River Reserve. I also received your petition for a change in the school administration at Bloodvein.

The list of children at Berens River went forward by the last mail from this office, but I beg to direct your attention to the fact that we receive mail only once per week and despatch mail once per week from this office.

I shall at once send your petition to the Department for consideration, but referring to your request that it be accompanied by my recommendation I would say that I cannot do this. You will readily see that if Your Church had been established in a reserve for some years and an Agent made a recommendation that a school under your auspices be transferred to the auspices of a Protestant Church, it would appear to you most unjust.

My office demands that I be fair to all Indians in my Agency, among whom there are many of different faiths; and to be quite frank I am of the opinion that all Indian schools should not be under the auspices of any Church. I most certainly think that the Churches should be encouraged and assisted to take the Gospel to our Indians, but education is one of the treaty stipulations of the treaties and should be given to the Indians whether Pagan or Christian.

The present policy of denominational schools to which you yourself object in the present Berens River School, seems to be only a cause of strife and a hindrance to proper education.

In reply I have to say, with reference to the erection of a new school building at the Fort Alexander Indian Day School, that we will have no funds this year to carry out this work, but to provide a residence for the teacher at the Brokenhead Indian Day School.

Your obedient servant,

A. P. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

W. H. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
A new teacher has been recently appointed for this school, Mr. G. W. McKelvey, who holds a second class certificate. I believe Mr. McKelvey is a very good teacher, and the attendance has been very good since he took charge. I happened to be at the school during the noon hour, and therefore did not inspect the classroom work. The teacher informed me that there were 18 Indian and 17 non-Indian children attending.

However,

BROKENHEAD INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

However, the children here are a little backward on account of the fact that some of the teachers we have had here have been more of the Missionary type than teachers. Therefore, they have not obtained the results which could be expected. However, with a qualified teacher in charge, better results can now be expected.

I wish to again remind the Department that a teacher's residence is badly required at this point. The present teacher is living in the old mission house about two miles from the school, but until we get a new residence here it will be hard to keep a suitable man as teacher at this school. I am aware that the Department have no funds at the present time, but am merely pointing this out so that it will not be lost sight of.

In conclusion, I wish to point out that the schools inspected are doing as good work as can be expected.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Re: Building Programme

I received word today from Mr. Campbell of the Canada Cement stating both cars of cement can be made available.

The one car for Hodgson will be shipped August 6th and Mr. Wylie has been notified to be ready to take delivery. The car for Norway House will be shipped as instructed, 450 bags for Norway House and 180 bags to Scantebury for the prefabricated school residence on the Brokenhead Reserve. I expect this car will be spotted August 4th and delivery will be made to Scantebury either by freight or truck.

The crib work for the basement of this residence is under construction now and the cement work should be completed from ten to twelve days. I have already notified North American Lumber Company and they will try to have the house ready for delivery.

There is a tremendous shortage of nails and I learned today that the Central Mortgage and Housing have a supply on hand. I consulted Mr. McClaskey and I feel confident he will release 2 kegs of 2", 2½" and 3½". These will be required for the school residence at Gypsumville in connection with the crib work and for building purposes at Norway House. A voucher will be forwarded shortly and I hope my making the purchase will be approved.

We will get the school residence at Fairfield started as soon as help can be obtained to do the basement. If no one else is available we will try to persuade the carpenter now working on the Brokenhead residence to take on this work.

Further reports will be submitted from time to time on the progress made.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 24th instant, with reference to Mr. Armand LaFleche, teacher of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School. Even though an increase were given Mr. LaFleche, it would be a small amount, and I agree with you that in his own best interests he should endeavour to secure more remunerative employment. The present seems an opportune time for him to act in this way. In making this statement I do not wish to imply that we are not satisfied with his services, because all reports indicate that he has done splendid work. However, as you know, there is a limit to salaries of teachers of Indian day schools beyond which we cannot go.

We will keep your recommendation in mind, and in the event of Mr. LaFleche deciding to stay in our employment for another year, arrangements will be made to grant him a small increase before October first.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

When I first joined the Dept. of Indian Affairs, 6 years ago, I had hoped that my experience as a teacher in the public schools of Man., as well as my University degree and my Normal School training would qualify me in time for a good position in the Department.

These six years have furnished me ample opportunities to familiarize myself with all problems pertaining to Indian welfare and education. I have always liked the work and still do.

But, there being no chance for me for advancement, (at least for the time being), I sincerely believe that to prolong my staying here would bring more harm than good both to myself and to my family.

Many a time I have declined offers to teach in the High Schools of Manitoba. To-day, in spite of my deep interest in Indian affairs (an interest which will never die out altogether), I am forced to send in my resignation as Teacher of the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

I shall be leaving Monday, September 1st, for Deloraine, Man., to become Assistant-Principal in the High School.

Before closing, may I recommend Mr. Leon Trottier, now with me, as my successor. This gentleman whom I have known for several years (he was my pupil at one time), has just completed his second year of Arts at the University of Manitoba. Last June he stayed with me for some time and I had him teach school a little. I know the boy has the real stuff to become a successful teacher. He is very good at manual work and is trustworthy in every way.

I want to thank you for everything your Department has done both for me and for my good friends at Whitefish.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Extract from Inspector Greening's report on the Whitefish Bay Indian Day School visited on February 19, 1943.

The scarcity of teachers is making it increasingly difficult to secure completely satisfactory teachers for these little schools so far from the bright lights of the cities.

Mr. Allard is the second extremely youthful young man who has been sent to this school in as many years, quite devoid of professional training or experience.

He is, quite noticeably, in deadly earnest and doing his very best. Perhaps I am a little too sympathetic towards young people who are obviously doing their utmost to fill positions, in these days of stress, for which they are not any too well prepared; and so I told Mr. Allard that I thought that he was doing as well as could be expected and that, if it depended on my report, there would be no reason why he could not return to Whitefish Bay next year if he wished. Having recorded this, my conscience is now clear upon the matter.

For the sake of the pupils, however, it is to be hoped that this frequent changing of teachers is not to become a too regular habit. Mr. Trottier, the last teacher, had not reached the age of 21, and so has since been called up for military service. Mr. Allard seems to be in very much the same boat.

A suggestion is made that the employment of young men within military call-up age groups cannot make for a great deal of continuity in planning or teaching.

Mr. Lafleche who had this school until June, 1941, was, admittedly, an unusually capable teacher, and one whom any successor would find it hard to succeed; but one has not to be very long at Whitefish Bay to notice the change that the passage of two years of unqualified teachers has made.

Re: Mr. Peter Fenez, Teacher
Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

A letter from the above noted has been received, and a copy is attached for your information. I would respectfully submit the following comments relating to Mr. Fenez's letter.

For some time past, the teacher has intimated to me that he could get a higher salary at other Agency Day Schools; particularly in the Port Arthur Agency; and the matter was discussed by him with Mr. Greenway, the Catholic School Inspector.

This in itself seems very irregular to me. First, in that there seem to be different salaries offered to teachers in the different agencies, and a higher salary in some instances to teachers having very much smaller attendance than at the Whitefish Bay School.

Secondly, I do not favour, as an Agent having a School Inspector discussing the matter of wages or inducing a settled teacher such as Mr. Fenez, to make a change. Mr. Fenez has done a very good job at Whitefish Bay and I feel confident in verifying the statements in his letter. Our associations have been cordial and we have worked together in a cooperative sense to the benefit of the pupils at the school.

Mr. Fenez took unto himself a wife last September, and no doubt feels that it is up to him to better himself, and I in no way would desire to step in his way. However, if an increase in salary is in order under your present regulations, and money available, I would recommend this request be given your favourable consideration.

None is irreplaceable, but after giving some considerable time to the welfare and betterment of the Whitefish Bay pupils, I feel that changing and replacing teachers of Mr. Fenez's calibre, is not conducive to the advancement of our Indian children; regardless whether there may be teachers having special certificates, or not, as teachers with first hand knowledge of Indians are not easy to find.

Please do not consider the foregoing critical to Department methods. I only wish to place before you, in a small measure, my ideas in regard to the welfare and betterment of our Indian Day School pupils and give some encouragement to the Day School teachers as a group.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.
