Dear Miss Terrance,

Re: Whitefish Bay Indian Day School.

Receipt is acknowledged of your letter dated the 10th of November, inquiring as to the location etc., of the a/n Day School.

This school is situated on the Whitefish Bay I.R. #32A, approximately 50 miles South East of Kenora.

It is accessible by Highway, Lake and Air. The Fort Frances Highway runs about 1 mile South of Sansons Landing, which is situated on a Bay lying south of the Reserve and is roughly 1 mile by Lake from the Day School. In the summer months, access to Reserve is made by outboards or canoes. During the freeze up walking from the highway or transportation by pony is the only means of travel. A daily bus service from Kenora serves the District.

There is a population of 180 on this Reserve composed of 56 men, 40 women and 87 boys and 53 girls under the age of 21. An average of 50 pupils are in attendance at this school. They are predominantly of the Catholic Faith with some few Protestants and pagans.

There is no R.C. Church on the Reserve. The Rev. Father Antonio Lascelle, O.M.I., is the missionary for this district and holds services in the school house periodically. There is a small R.C. Mission situated on the Fort Frances Highway near Sioux Narrows; this being about 10 miles from the Reserve.

The Band members on this Reserve make their living by Commercial Fishing, guiding and trapping. At Sioux Narrows there is a Post Office, Day School and 3 or 4 stores. This is a busy community during the summer months serving and catering to the tourist trade.

The present teacher, Mr. Peter Fonesz is married and have a little girl 2 years old. They are of French Canadian stock from Manitoba. Mr. and Mrs. Fonesz are a very nice couple and have taken a great interest in the welfare of this Band and have made many friends in and around Sioux Narrows.

Attendance, etc.

As the people take their children away with them when hunting this necessitates a poor school attendance, and a rough unsavoury bunch when they do attend. The remedy for this state of things lies with the Government through the Department by either imposing and enforcing compulsory attendance at school or by providing some means so that the children could be left behind, fed, cared for and attend school while their parents were hunting.

The progress in the school room is slow on account of the reasons given above. I would suggest that the reserve policeman be paid a small salary by the Department to act as truant officer.

Sgd. Richard G.V. Cooper,
Teacher.
On my arrival at Chemawawin Reserve I found that the School had been closed for about three weeks. Several days for want of wood, the rest of the time the teacher being sick.

The Doctor examined this man and reports him in bad shape internally and advised him to go into civilization for treatment at once. His ailment is caused principally from want of fresh air and exercise, and from appearance and all accounts the man is absolutely lazy. His own house and the school are a poor example for the Indians in cleanliness. There is a general complaint that this school is very irregular, and I would recommend that Mr. Cooper be asked for his resignation to take effect at the end of the present quarter, and Mrs Morris, the Missionary's wife, be appointed. She takes a personal interest in the Indians, has about thirty children attending her Sunday School, and her influence can be seen in every house on that Reserve. I have no doubt with her standing among the Indians, the attendance at this school could be doubled and some improvement shown. According to the Indians Mr. Cooper never investigated absences or took any personal interest in the children outside of the school.

I was nominated for the position which I hold as Teacher of Chenaawavin Reserve Indian Day School in February 1914 by His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan and appointed by your Department as per your letter No. 118338/1, dated February 28th 1914.

Towards the end of last year Mr. W.R. Taylor, the Indian Agent at The Pas, vacated his position to join the Army, and early this year a new man (Mr. S.G. Macdonald) was appointed Agent. He signs himself as "Acting Indian Agent".

At the end of January last he visited this Reserve for the first time as Agent accompanied by a Doctor, Dr. Bailey of The Pas.

Unfortunately I was laid up at that time suffering from a severe attack of influenza which kept me away from school for 10 days. I was convalescent but not well enough to attend to my school duties when Mr. Macdonald arrived.

I told him and the Doctor that I had no accommodation at my house (which possesses only one small room) to give them hospitality for the night and I referred them to the Mission house where the Rev. L. Morris and his wife are in occupation and also where the late Agent Mr. Taylor has often stayed.

Whether Mr. Macdonald took offence...
or not I do not know, but last Saturday
the 17th inst. I received a most unexpected
and extraordinary letter from him, a
copy of which I enclose.

In that letter, as you will observe, he
makes 3 charges against me which are
absolutely groundless and unfair, the second
one being quite devoid of any truth, and
then he demands that I send in my
resignation and hand the School over to
Mr. Morris who is the wife of the Rev.
C. Morris the local resident Minister
here!

Mr. Macdonald states—“In view of
1 complaints by the Indians and the
2 very poor showing of the Chemawin
School and 3 partly on account of the
Doctor’s report of your physical condition”

I would ask you to kindly allow me
to briefly point out the unfairness of
Mr. Macdonald’s charges against me.

In a few days I will have completed
a period of 3 years work at this school,
and during all this time I have never
heard of any complaints from the people
here regarding my work but have received
a good deal of praise for the same.

Mr. Macdonald’s unfairness in his first
charge of “Complaints by the Indians” is
evident when I state that he has never
written to me stating the nature of these
complaints nor asked me whether they were
true or not. He confronts me without hearing
my defense and uses this charge as a just
reason for demanding my resignation!
Everyone who has worked for any length of time among the Indians knows that they are always making "Complaints" and for an Indian Agent to give such "Complaints" as a reason for the condemnation of the work of a Teacher, indicates that that Agent must be very hard up for valid reasons for a justifiable condemnation.

The second charge of "the very poor showing of the Chemawowin School" is absolutely untrue. The late Indian Agent (Mr Taylor) has generally expressed himself as quite satisfied with the Educational progress of this school and he has from time to time made a report in the Register to that effect. He has never expressed dissatisfaction in any way. But the ridiculousness of Mr Macdonald's charge on this point is that he has not visited the school at all, as I was ill at home at the time of his first and only visit to this Reserve! He charges me with the "poor showing" of this School when he has never entered the School door!

I doubt very much if he had been present at the school during an examination of the children that his report would have been of much value for he is very deaf.

When Inspector Jackson, Indian School Inspector last visited this Reserve in July, 1916 he reported that the Classes in my school here were a good deal in advance of the same Classes in most other Indian schools.

And lastly—his charge of the "Doctor's report of my physical condition". I had an interview with the Doctor for about 10 minutes.
only. I told him that I was just recovering from a severe attack of Influenza and that I had also had some tapeworms during the last 6 months but otherwise was all right.

He told me that he thought that town life would suit me better than the country and then he gave me a prescription for some medicine. That was all. I am now quite well and do all my own chores and can hold my own with most men of my age (48).

I took over this school from a young minister who had sadly neglected it for over 2 years. Not a child in the school could read more than a few of the simplest words and none could add up more than a single column of figures.

I have now 3 children doing the Compound rules with problems in Arithmetic (one a girl who has just turned 11 years) and 6 are using the Second Reader and reading very well. Hygiene is carefully taught, morals, Religious instruction, Geography, Grammar, Singing, Calisthenics &c.

I purchased a large set of dumb bells for the children to drill with and I have made 10 different articles of furniture for the school.

Last July on Treaty-payment day Inspector Jackson and the late Indian Agent (Mr Taylor) nominated me for the position of Police Magistrate for this Reserve. I was duly appointed in October last and have just dealt with my first two cases—one of drunkenness and the other of wife-assault. Last October...
your Department kindly purchased a Teacher's house here well fitted up with good equipment for storing the Reserve drugs.

If I am forced to resign this house must be closed, as Mrs. Morris (the Minister's wife who was offered the position of Teacher by Mr. Macdonald) lives at the mission house with her husband; the distribution of the Rations must be left to the tender mercies of the Indians as a woman-teacher cannot do this work, and my Magisterial work and Office must come to an end as there is no one else here willing or capable of filling that position.

In stating the above facts of this matter so fully to your Department I have not done so through being over anxious to retain my position here as Teacher and Police Magistrate, but I am naturally desirous of frustrating, if possible, any attempt to force me to resign through bare-faced misrepresentation and perversion of the truth.

In conclusion I beg to say that I leave with confidence this matter entirely in the hands of your Department and if the letter which I have received from the Agent has been authorized by your Department, then I ask you to kindly reconsider this matter in the light of the facts which I have enumerated above and upon receipt of your decision the same will receive my prompt and willing compliance.

Yours faithfully,

Richard S. Cooper.

Sir,

I have the honor to report that I visited the day school at Chawawin Reserve on the 10th inst., and I examined the pupils etc., with following results.

The register showed 6 boys and 9 girls in attendance.

The school had been open for 47 days up to time of my visit since beginning of the quarter. The average attendance up to that time was 11.

In grade 3 there were 2 boys and 2 girls. I examined these children and they were very backward in reading and spelling from third book. They could do simple addition, but could not divide, or subtract, and knew very little of multiplication.

The ones in grade two were also very backward in every study.

The children in the A.R.C. class had only been taught their alphabet, they did not know the figures from 1 to 10, and the teacher said he had not come to that yet.

I have protected this old chap and tried to get him to make progress but it seems a useless job, there is nothing I can do in the case except to recommend that he be replaced. I think the Department should see if the Church authorities cannot replace him. His name is J.G. Kennedy, and he has taught for years, gradually getting worse. I hate to recommend anything of this sort, but have to look at the question from the standpoint of the children.

Mr. Kennedy told me the children had not been attending school regularly, but he had his register marked up without any breaks. I did not enquire of the parents if the children had been attending steadily, but think the register is plugged.

There is not much progress here.

"The Indians at this place are about the most poverty stricken lot I have seen. I hardly know what to recommend about it, but it appears to me that on account of having to stop home to keep the children at the school they just about starve themselves as there is no game to be obtained locally. The school is closed more or less every spring for the rat hunt and there will be few people home in March and April. It appears as if we should operate this place as a summer school only; the Indians could keep alive then by fishing. Then in the fall and winter they could go off to some district where they could get moose, fish and rabbits. I wish the Department would take the matter up with the church authorities and have the matter discussed. I do not want my opinion to be taken as the only solution of the matter, but if you saw these half-starved people sitting in empty shacks with nothing to eat you would feel like making a change of some sort, I am sure."

Dear Sir:

I wish to report that Mr. P. Barrett, teacher of the Chemawawin Indian Day School at Cedar Lake, Manitoba, was brought to The Pas late last night by canoe, suffering from typhoid fever.

After getting him to the Hospital, and seeing him as comfortable as he could be, I had a talk with him, but he states that there are no Indians at Cedar Lake sick just now.

As you will remember five Cedar Lake Indians were brought to The Pas the beginning of October with typhoid, but one died, and the other four returned just a week ago.

On talking the matter over with Dr. Robertson, the Doctor said he did not think we would have any more cases from Cedar Lake as the five that were brought in were at a camp some 35 miles away from the reserve.

However when the Doctor was at Cedar Lake recently, he made arrangements with Mr. McDonald, the Hudson's Bay Company Manager, to get this office know immediately if he had any suspicions of another outbreak, and so far no word had been received here.

Should anything arise from this I will let you know immediately, and trust this will meet with your approval.
